As of the latest information, here are some of the most notable rare earth elements and minerals found in New Zealand:\n\n### **1. **Neodymium (Nd)**\n\n- **Uses**: Neodymium is crucial for manufacturing high-strength magnets used in various technologies, including electric motors, wind turbines, and hard disk drives.\n- **Occurrences**: Found in several deposits and is often associated with other rare earth minerals.\n\n### **2. **Yttrium (Y)**\n\n- **Uses**: Yttrium is used in phosphors for LEDs and in various high-tech applications, including superconductors and ceramic materials.\n- **Occurrences**: Present in mineral deposits and can be extracted as a byproduct of mining other rare earth minerals.\n\n### **3. **Lanthanum (La)**\n\n- **Uses**: Lanthanum is used in batteries, catalysts, and glassmaking.\n- **Occurrences**: Often found in association with other rare earth elements in mineral deposits.\n\n### **4. **Cerium (Ce)**\n\n- **Uses**: Cerium is used in catalytic converters, glass polishing, and as a component in various alloys.\n- **Occurrences**: Commonly found in rare earth deposits in New Zealand.\n\n### **5. **Dysprosium (Dy)**\n\n- **Uses**: Dysprosium is used in high-performance magnets and in various technological applications.\n- **Occurrences**: Found in certain rare earth deposits, although less common than some other elements.\n\n### **6. **Gadolinium (Gd)**\n\n- **Uses**: Gadolinium is used in medical imaging (MRI contrast agents) and in various alloys and phosphors.\n- **Occurrences**: Present in some of New Zealand\u2019s rare earth mineral deposits.\n\n### **Notable Deposits and Locations:**\n\n1. **Bentonite Deposits**: Certain bentonite deposits in New Zealand contain significant amounts of rare earth elements. These deposits are found in various locations, including parts of the North Island.\n\n2. **Heavy Mineral Sands**: The West Coast of the South Island has been noted for its heavy mineral sands, which can contain rare earth elements, particularly in placer deposits.\n\n3. **Phosphate Deposits**: Some phosphate deposits in New Zealand, like those found in the region around the Bay of Plenty, have been identified to contain rare earth elements.\n\n### **Exploration and Research:**\n\nNew Zealand has been actively exploring and researching rare earth mineral deposits to better understand their potential for economic extraction. The country\u2019s geological surveys and mining companies continue to investigate the scale, quality, and commercial viability of these resources.\n\n### **Conclusion**\n\nWhile several rare earth elements are present in New Zealand\u2019s deposits, the focus is often on those that are most commercially valuable and in demand, such as neodymium, yttrium, lanthanum, cerium, dysprosium, and gadolinium. The extraction and processing of these elements are subject to ongoing research to optimize their recovery and utilization."]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": true, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"citations": [], "content_references": [], "gizmo_id": null, "message_type": null, "model_slug": "gpt-4o-mini", "default_model_slug": "auto", "model_adjustments": ["auto:smaller_model:reached_message_cap"], "pad": "AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA", "parent_id": "aaa2dfcd-2e84-42f8-83d2-df2abfa46eea", "finish_details": {"type": "stop", "stop_tokens": [200002]}, "is_complete": true, "request_id": "8b989d17c9bf1c53-AKL", "timestamp_": "absolute"}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "aaa2dfcd-2e84-42f8-83d2-df2abfa46eea", "children": ["aaa2d472-ed63-4882-ac2d-3fb35c77ab85"]}, "aaa2d472-ed63-4882-ac2d-3fb35c77ab85": {"id": "aaa2d472-ed63-4882-ac2d-3fb35c77ab85", "message": {"id": "aaa2d472-ed63-4882-ac2d-3fb35c77ab85", "author": {"role": "user", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1724725625.011132, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["starting with neodymium what are the byproducts of extraction and purification?"]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": null, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"request_id": "8b989ed1aa901c53-AKL", "message_source": null, "timestamp_": "absolute", "message_type": null}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "d02ef28f-aeaa-4548-ab31-198a57033182", "children": ["52d6b8d8-6260-498c-ac12-29546e747cdd"]}, "52d6b8d8-6260-498c-ac12-29546e747cdd": {"id": "52d6b8d8-6260-498c-ac12-29546e747cdd", "message": {"id": "52d6b8d8-6260-498c-ac12-29546e747cdd", "author": {"role": "assistant", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1724725636.294377, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["The extraction and purification of neodymium, a rare earth element, involve several steps, each of which can produce different byproducts. Here\u2019s a breakdown of the typical byproducts generated during the neodymium extraction and purification process:\n\n### **1. **Mining and Crushing**\n\n- **Byproducts**: During the initial mining and crushing of ore, large amounts of waste rock and tailings are generated. These materials often contain low concentrations of rare earth elements and other minerals.\n\n### **2. **Beneficiation**\n\n- **Byproducts**: Beneficiation processes, such as flotation or gravity separation, produce tailings that are often rich in gangue minerals and other unwanted materials. These tailings may contain trace amounts of rare earth elements and other potentially valuable minerals.\n\n### **3. **Leaching**\n\n- **Byproducts**: In the leaching stage, chemicals such as sulfuric acid or hydrochloric acid are used to dissolve rare earth elements from the ore. Byproducts include:\n\n  - **Acid Waste**: Spent acids or acid solutions that need to be neutralized or treated to prevent environmental contamination.\n  - **Iron and Other Metal Salts**: Iron and other metal salts that are leached from the ore along with the rare earth elements.\n\n### **4. **Solvent Extraction**\n\n- **Byproducts**: Solvent extraction is used to separate neodymium from other rare earth elements. Byproducts include:\n\n  - **Organic Solvent Waste**: Used organic solvents, such as kerosene or phosphoric acid, which need to be recovered or treated.\n  - **Wastewater**: Containing residual solvents and other chemicals from the extraction process.\n\n### **5. **Precipitation and Separation**\n\n- **Byproducts**: During precipitation, where rare earth elements are converted into solid compounds for separation, byproducts include:\n\n  - **Precipitation Sludge**: Solid residues that include precipitated rare earth compounds and impurities.\n  - **Secondary Salts**: Various salts formed during the precipitation process that need to be managed.\n\n### **6. **Purification and Refining**\n\n- **Byproducts**: The final purification and refining stages produce:\n\n  - **High-Purity Neodymium Oxide**: The desired product, but also residual impurities.\n  - **Residual Waste**: Contains impurities removed during purification, which may include various metal oxides and other compounds.\n\n### **7. **Environmental and Safety Concerns**\n\n- **Radioactive Materials**: Some rare earth ores contain trace amounts of radioactive materials such as thorium or uranium, which can be a concern if not properly managed.\n- **Toxic Chemicals**: Handling of toxic chemicals like acids and solvents requires careful management to prevent environmental contamination and health risks.\n\n### **Overall Byproduct Management**\n\n1. **Neutralization and Treatment**: Acid wastes and other toxic byproducts are treated to neutralize or detoxify them before disposal or recycling.\n\n2. **Recycling and Recovery**: Efforts are made to recycle solvents and recover valuable byproducts to reduce waste and improve efficiency.\n\n3. **Disposal**: Non-recyclable byproducts are disposed of in compliance with environmental regulations and standards.\n\n### **Conclusion**\n\nThe extraction and purification of neodymium generate a variety of byproducts, including waste rock, tailings, chemical residues, and secondary salts. Effective management of these byproducts is essential to minimize environmental impact and ensure sustainability in rare earth mineral processing."]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": true, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"citations": [], "content_references": [], "gizmo_id": null, "message_type": null, "model_slug": "gpt-4o-mini", "default_model_slug": "auto", "model_adjustments": ["auto:smaller_model:reached_message_cap"], "pad": "AAAAAAAAAAAAA", "parent_id": "aaa2d472-ed63-4882-ac2d-3fb35c77ab85", "finish_details": {"type": "stop", "stop_tokens": [200002]}, "is_complete": true, "request_id": "8b989ed1aa901c53-AKL", "timestamp_": "absolute"}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "aaa2d472-ed63-4882-ac2d-3fb35c77ab85", "children": ["aaa20e11-6eb9-429f-aa21-64e80a4da359"]}, "aaa20e11-6eb9-429f-aa21-64e80a4da359": {"id": "aaa20e11-6eb9-429f-aa21-64e80a4da359", "message": {"id": "aaa20e11-6eb9-429f-aa21-64e80a4da359", "author": {"role": "user", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1724725719.473015, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["what industries could make use of the waste from **3 & **4?"]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": null, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"request_id": "8b98a11fee931c53-AKL", "message_source": null, "timestamp_": "absolute", "message_type": null}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "52d6b8d8-6260-498c-ac12-29546e747cdd", "children": ["6aa294ae-5ffe-4115-8d2f-f75dcdf5f69c"]}, "6aa294ae-5ffe-4115-8d2f-f75dcdf5f69c": {"id": "6aa294ae-5ffe-4115-8d2f-f75dcdf5f69c", "message": {"id": "6aa294ae-5ffe-4115-8d2f-f75dcdf5f69c", "author": {"role": "assistant", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1724725731.734751, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["The waste products generated from the leaching (3) and solvent extraction (4) stages of neodymium extraction can potentially be repurposed or utilized in several industries. Here's how these byproducts might be used:\n\n### **1. **Acid Waste (from Leaching)**\n\n**Industries and Applications:**\n\n- **Construction Materials**: Acid waste neutralized and treated can be used in the production of construction materials such as cement and concrete. For example, certain neutralized sludges can be incorporated into cement as supplementary cementitious materials.\n  \n- **Agriculture**: Treated acid waste could potentially be used in soil conditioning or as a fertilizer, provided it is processed to remove harmful components and meet safety standards.\n\n- **Water Treatment**: Acid wastes, once neutralized, might be used in water treatment processes. For instance, treated materials can be utilized in the treatment of wastewater or in the removal of contaminants from drinking water.\n\n### **2. **Iron and Other Metal Salts (from Leaching)**\n\n**Industries and Applications:**\n\n- **Metallurgical Industry**: Byproducts containing iron salts can be used in the production of steel or other metallurgical processes. They may be processed into iron ore or used as additives in steelmaking.\n\n- **Pigments and Dyes**: Iron and other metal salts can be used in the manufacture of pigments and dyes for various industrial applications, including paints, inks, and textiles.\n\n- **Catalysts**: Certain metal salts are used as catalysts in chemical reactions. The byproducts could potentially be utilized in the production of chemical catalysts for industrial processes.\n\n### **3. **Organic Solvent Waste (from Solvent Extraction)**\n\n**Industries and Applications:**\n\n- **Solvent Recycling**: Organic solvents can be recovered and recycled for reuse in extraction processes or other chemical applications. Specialized recycling facilities can distill and purify spent solvents for future use.\n\n- **Chemical Manufacturing**: Recovered solvents can be used in the manufacture of various chemicals or as intermediates in industrial chemical processes.\n\n- **Cleaning Agents**: Organic solvents, after proper treatment and recycling, might be used in industrial cleaning processes or as degreasers.\n\n### **4. **Wastewater (from Solvent Extraction)**\n\n**Industries and Applications:**\n\n- **Wastewater Treatment**: Wastewater containing residual solvents and other contaminants can be treated and processed in wastewater treatment facilities to remove harmful substances. Treated water can potentially be recycled or safely discharged.\n\n- **Energy Recovery**: In some cases, wastewater treatment facilities can utilize waste energy or heat from the treatment process for energy recovery, contributing to overall sustainability.\n\n### **5. **Precipitation Sludge and Secondary Salts (from Precipitation)**\n\n**Industries and Applications:**\n\n- **Mining and Metal Recovery**: Precipitation sludge might contain valuable secondary metals or rare earth elements that can be recovered and reused in mining or metal production.\n\n- **Ceramics and Glass**: Some of the precipitated materials, if properly processed, could be used in the ceramics and glass industries as raw materials or additives.\n\n- **Waste Stabilization**: Precipitation sludge can be stabilized and used as a construction material or in other applications where stabilization and safe disposal are required.\n\n### **Overall Waste Management Strategy**\n\nEfficient management of these byproducts often involves:\n\n- **Recovery and Recycling**: Maximizing the recovery and recycling of valuable components to minimize waste.\n- **Neutralization and Treatment**: Treating hazardous wastes to neutralize harmful substances and make them suitable for reuse or safe disposal.\n- **Innovation**: Exploring new uses and applications for byproducts to reduce environmental impact and improve resource efficiency.\n\nIf you have more specific interests in how these byproducts might be utilized or if you need information on particular applications, let me know!"]}, "status": "parts": ["During the time of Jesus, around the 1st century CE, the Middle East had access to a few natural substances with psychoactive properties, though they weren't commonly referred to as \"psychedelics\" in the modern sense. Some of these include:\n\n1. **Mandrake** (*Mandragora officinarum*): Known for its roots resembling human figures, mandrake was believed to have aphrodisiac and hallucinogenic properties. It was used in various rituals and medicines.\n\n2. **Opium**: Derived from the poppy plant (*Papaver somniferum*), opium was used for its sedative and pain-relieving effects, but in higher doses, it could cause altered states of consciousness.\n\n3. **Syrian Rue** (*Peganum harmala*): This plant contains harmala alkaloids, which are MAO inhibitors and can have psychoactive effects. It was sometimes used in traditional rituals.\n\n4. **Cannabis**: There is evidence that cannabis was used in various parts of the ancient world, including the Middle East, primarily for its medicinal properties, but it could also be used to induce altered states.\n\nThese substances were generally used in ritualistic or medicinal contexts rather than recreationally as in modern times."]}, consciousness could have influenced the religious narratives and mystical traditions of the ancient world, including those that shaped the religions we know today. Here's how that could have played out:\n\n1. **Mystical Visions and Revelations**: In ancient cultures, mystical experiences were often interpreted as direct communication with the divine. If someone consumed a substance like mandrake, opium, or even encountered naturally occurring ergot (a fungus with LSD-like properties), they might have had vivid visions. These could easily be interpreted as spiritual revelations or divine encounters, which could be passed down through oral traditions.\n\n2. **Ritual Use of Psychoactive Plants**: Many ancient religions incorporated psychoactive plants into their rituals. Over time, the original context of these rituals might have been forgotten or altered, but the stories and myths born from these experiences could survive, evolving into the religious texts or traditions we know today.\n\n3. **Oral Tradition and Embellishment**: Stories passed down orally often change with each retelling, a process similar to the \"Chinese whispers\" game. An individual's intense spiritual or hallucinatory experience could have been exaggerated or reinterpreted over generations, turning personal visions into grand religious narratives or miracles.\n\n4. **Mystery Religions and Esoteric Practices**: In the ancient Mediterranean, mystery religions like those dedicated to Dionysus or the Eleusinian Mysteries involved secret rituals, sometimes believed to involve psychoactive substances. These could have influenced early Christian or Gnostic practices, contributing to the development of mystical or symbolic aspects of these religions.\n\nWhile direct evidence is scarce due to the passage of time and the secretive nature of many ancient rituals, the idea that altered states of consciousness played a role in the formation of religious myths and experiences is plausible. It adds an intriguing layer to the understanding of how ancient beliefs might have evolved into the major religions we see today."]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": true, "weight": claim that any single factor, like the use of psychedelics, holds *the* answer to the big questions about the origins of religious beliefs or mystical experiences. The development of religious thought is a complex, multifaceted process influenced by a wide range of factors, including:\n\n1. **Cultural Context**: Religious beliefs are shaped by the cultural and historical context in which they develop. This includes existing myths, rituals, societal needs, and the ways people understand the world around them.\n\n2. **Psychological Factors**: Human psychology plays a huge role in religious experiences. Dreams, visions, meditation, and other altered states of consciousness\u2014induced naturally or through substances\u2014can all contribute to the formation of spiritual beliefs.\n\n3. **Social Dynamics**: Religious ideas often spread and evolve through social dynamics, including power structures, community cohesion, and the need for shared identity.\n\n4. **Philosophical Inquiry**: Many religious concepts also emerge from deep philosophical inquiry and debate, reflecting humanity\u2019s quest to understand existence, morality, and the nature of the divine.\n\n5. **Psychedelic Experiences**: While they may have influenced specific mystical experiences or traditions, psychedelics are just one piece of the puzzle. Their role in shaping broader religious narratives is difficult to isolate and prove definitively.\n\nIn sum, psychedelics could have contributed to the formation of certain religious ideas, but they are far from being the sole or definitive answer. Religion is the product of a complex interplay of cultural, psychological, social, and philosophical factors, making it impossible to attribute its origins to any one cause in isolation."]}, "status": These experiences often involve feelings of profound connection, love, and the presence of a benevolent, higher power that cares deeply for the individual.\n\nIn many DMT experiences, people report encountering entities that seem overwhelmingly powerful yet deeply compassionate, sometimes described as god-like or angelic. The idea of these entities expressing love and concern for the individual is a common theme, which does echo the concept of a deity who sacrifices itself for humanity's benefit, as seen in the Christian narrative of Jesus Christ.\n\nThis similarity raises interesting questions about the origins of religious ideas. If people in ancient times had experiences through altered states of consciousness\u2014whether induced by psychedelics, fasting, meditation, or other means\u2014it's conceivable that such experiences could have contributed to the development of religious stories and doctrines. Over time, these mystical encounters might have been interpreted as encounters with the divine, forming the basis for religious beliefs centered around a loving, sacrificial god.\n\nHowever, while this idea is fascinating, it's essential to approach it with caution. The similarities between psychedelic experiences and religious narratives don't necessarily mean one caused the other. The human mind, across cultures and contexts, seems to be wired for certain kinds of spiritual experiences, whether they're triggered by natural processes or substances. These experiences may simply tap into a deeper, universal aspect of human consciousness that expresses itself in similar ways across different contexts, whether through religion or psychedelics.\n\nSo, while the parallels are compelling, they are one part of a much broader and more complex story about the origins and evolution of religious beliefs."]}, "status": "tether_quote", "url": "https://kaempathogenics.com/blogs/plants/kanna-legal", "domain": "kaempathogenics.com", "text": "\nKanna, kava kava and cannabis have different legal statuses in various countries. Here is a general overview:\n\n### Kanna\n\nIn most countries, including the United States (except in Louisiana), Canada and much of Europe, Kanna is legal. It is not regulated or controlled in the U.S.\u00a0 Woot!\n\n### Kava kava\n\nThe legal status of kava kava varies by country. It is legal in most countries, including the United States, Canada and much of Europe. Due to concerns of liver toxicity, many countries including Australia, Canada, France, Germany, Japan, Malaysia, Norway, Poland, Singapore, South Africa, Sweden, Switzerland, and the United Kingdom have placed regulatory controls on kava.\u00a0\n\n### Cannabis\n\nThe legal status of cannabis also varies by country. In some countries, such as Uruguay, Mexico, South Africa, Thailand and Canada, cannabis is legal for recreational use. Many countries have adopted a policy of decriminalization to make simple possession a non-criminal offense (often similar to a minor traffic violation). Others have much more severe penalties such as some Asian and Middle Eastern countries where possession of even small amounts is punished by imprisonment for several years. In other countries, such as the United States, it is legal in some places, but illegal in others. Legal status in the US also depends on whether it is for medical or recreational use on a state by state basis.\u00a0 Under federal law, cannabis still remains illegal in the United States.\n\n## Kanna safety and benefits\n\n[Image 2]\n\nKanna is a plant that's \u301024\u2020safe\u2020pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov\u3011^{1} to ingest. The alkaloids in Kanna, such as mesembrine and mesembrenone, interact with the brain and body in various ways. Here are some of the benefits of Kanna:\n\n  1. It boosts serotonin levels^{2}, positively affecting mood and decreasing anxiety and stress^{3} and helps people feel more connected and compassionate towards themselves and others.\n  2. It can aid in deep mental, emotional and bodily relaxation.\n  3. It can help boost energy levels without overwhelming the mind and body (see footnote 2).\n  4. It can improve problem-solving and cognitive function^{4}\n  5. It can enhance sleep quality.^{5}\n  6. It may have potential medical benefits such as neuroprotective and neuroregenerative properties that could help protect against cognitive decline due to aging or other illnesses such as Alzheimer's and Parkinson's.^{6}\n\nIt's important to note that individual experiences may vary. It's always recommended to get your Kanna from a reputable source with transparent alkaloid content (if an extract) and consult with a healthcare professional before trying any new supplement or plant medicine.\u00a0\n\n## Experience the KA!leidoscope of benefits\n\nKanna has a long history with the\u00a0Bushmen and Khoi of South Africa and Namibia, and its legal status, safety profile and potential health benefits make it an increasingly popular plant medicine. By being mindful of your unique experiences with Kanna, you can gain insights into how this plant medicine may impact your mental, emotional and physical well-being.\u00a0\n\nAt KA! Here is a general overview:\n\n### Kanna\n\nIn most countries, including the United States (except in Louisiana), Canada and much of Europe, Kanna is legal. It is not regulated or controlled in the U.S.\u00a0 Woot!\n\n### Kava kava\n\nThe legal status of kava kava varies by country. It is legal in most countries, including the United States, Canada and much of Europe. Due to concerns of liver toxicity, many countries including Australia, Canada, France, Germany, Japan, Malaysia, Norway, Poland, Singapore, South Africa, Sweden, Switzerland, and the United Kingdom have placed regulatory controls on kava.\u00a0\n\n### Cannabis\n\nThe legal status of cannabis also varies by country. In some countries, such as Uruguay, Mexico, South Africa, Thailand and Canada, cannabis is legal for recreational use. Many countries have adopted a policy of decriminalization to make simple possession a non-criminal offense (often similar to a minor traffic violation). Others have much more severe penalties such as some Asian and Middle Eastern countries where possession of even small amounts is punished by imprisonment for several years. In other countries, such as the United States, it is legal in some places, but illegal in others. Legal status in the US also depends on whether it is for medical or recreational use on a state by state basis.\u00a0 Under federal law, cannabis still remains illegal in the United States.\n\n## Kanna safety and benefits\n\n[Image 2]\n\nKanna is a plant that's \u301024\u2020safe\u2020pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov\u3011^{1} to ingest. It boosts serotonin levels^{2}, positively affecting mood and decreasing anxiety and stress^{3} and helps people feel more connected and compassionate towards themselves and others.\n  2. It can aid in deep mental, emotional and bodily relaxation.\n  3. It can help boost energy levels without overwhelming the mind and body (see footnote 2).\n  4. It can improve problem-solving and cognitive function^{4}\n  5. It can enhance sleep quality.^{5}\n  6. It may have potential medical benefits such as neuroprotective and neuroregenerative properties that could help protect against cognitive decline due to aging or other illnesses such as Alzheimer's and Parkinson's.^{6}\n\nIt's important to note that individual experiences may vary. It's always recommended to get your Kanna from a reputable source with transparent alkaloid content (if an extract) and consult with a healthcare professional before trying any new supplement or plant medicine.\u00a0\n\n## Experience the KA!leidoscope of benefits\n\nKanna has a long history with the\u00a0Bushmen and Khoi of South Africa and Namibia, and its legal status, safety profile and potential health benefits make it an increasingly popular plant medicine. the definition of a therapeutic purpose is given in the Medicines Act 1981.\n\n\u301062\u2020The Medsafe guideline on the Categorisation of Products can be used to determine whether a product is a dietary supplement\u3011.\n\n\u301063\u2020The Ministry for Primary Industries New Zealand Supplemented Food Standard \u2013 User Guide has a flow chart in chapter 4 which can help you decide whether your product is a dietary supplement or supplemented food.\u2020www.mpi.govt.nz\u3011\n\n* * *\n\n\u301061\u2020 \u3011\n\n#### Dietary Supplements containing Folic Acid\n\nThe maximum daily dose for a dietary supplement is 300 micrograms folic acid per day.\n\nHowever, the maximum daily dose of folic acid may be increased to 500 micrograms per day if the sponsor has demonstrated to Medsafe that the dietary supplement is manufactured in a Good Manufacturing Practice certified facility.\n\n\u301064\u2020Note that the Good Manufacturing Practice certification must meet the requirements specified in the Guideline for Therapeutic Products in New Zealand: Manufacture of Medicines\u3011 (PDF 136 KB, 9 pages).\n\nTo demonstrate that your product is manufactured in a Good Manufacturing Practice certified facility and to appropriate Good Manufacturing Practice standards you will need to:\n\n  1. \u301065\u2020Complete a declaration that the product is manufactured in a way that accords with the New Zealand Code of Good Manufacturing Practice using the Sponsor declaration form\u3011 (Microsoft Word document 50KB, 1 page)\n  2. \u301064\u2020Attach evidence of Good Manufacturing Practice compliance for the manufacturing site that is current, less than three years old and meets the requirements specified in the Guideline for Therapeutic products in New Zealand\u3011: Manufacture of Medicine (PDF 136 KB, 9 pages).\n  3. Send the completed declaration and Good Manufacturing Practice evidence to: dietarysupplements@health.govt.nz.  \n\nYou cannot legally supply dietary supplements containing more than 300 micrograms folic acid per daily dose until the Medsafe verified declaration has been returned to the sponsor. The verified declaration should be retained by the sponsor for at least one year after the expiry of the last batch supplied.\n\nIf Medsafe is not satisfied that all requirements are met the sponsor will be contacted.\n\nSponsor declarations are subject to audit. Medsafe reserves the right to request further details regarding the manufacturing arrangements and Good Manufacturing Practice compliance of the product while it remains on the market.\n\nA verified sponsor declaration remains valid if all details of the sponsor declaration remain unchanged. If changes are planned, the sponsor must submit an updated declaration and receive verification in advance of supplying the product to the New Zealand market.\n\nChanges that require a new declaration include (but are not limited to):\n\n  * sponsor details\n  * product name\n  * maximum daily dose\n  * manufacturing site\n  * packing site.\n\nIf the site manufacturing your product does not have acceptable Good Manufacturing Practice certification, you can contact the Compliance Management Branch of Medsafe to arrange a Good Manufacturing Practice audit. A service fee will apply to such audits in order to recover the time and travel costs associated with the audit.\n\nFor further information, contact the Compliance Management Branch on dietarysupplements@health.govt.nz.\n\n\u301066\u2020Questions and answers on requesting confirmation of GMP status for the manufacture of a dietary supplement containing folic acid with a daily dose of more than 300 mcg\u3011\n\n* * *\n\n\u301061\u2020 \u3011\n\n### Requirements under the Food Act\n\n#### Importing dietary supplements\n\nDietary supplements fall under the Food Act 2014. The Food Act requires import of all food for sale to be via a Registered Food Importer.\u00a0 If you are importing dietary supplements you must register as an importer with the Ministry for Primary Industries which has responsibility for administering the Food Act 2014.\n\nMPI lists registered food importers in a public database:\u00a0 See \u301067\u2020http://www.foodsafety.govt.nz/registers-lists/food-act-2014-registered-food-importers/index.htm\u2020www.foodsafety.govt.nz\u3011\n\n\u301068\u2020Information on how to register with the Ministry for Primary Industries is available on their website\u2020www.mpi.govt.nz\u3011 . There is a charge for registering as an importer.\n\n\u301069\u2020The New Zealand Customs Service is able to advise on the requirements (e.g., taxes, paperwork) for commercial importation into New Zealand\u2020www.customs.govt.nz\u3011.\n\nDietary supplements containing ingredients from animals and animal products are also subject to legislation set forth by the Biosecurity Act 1993. The biosecurity act legislation was enacted to protect New Zealand's environment, plants and animals from unwanted pests and diseases.\n\n* * *\n\n\u301061\u2020 \u3011\n\n#### Manufacturing and packing dietary supplements\n\nAs the Dietary Supplements Regulations 1985 fall under the Food Act 2014, dietary supplements should be manufactured, packed and sold in a manner that complies with the Food Act 2014 and the Food Regulations 2015.\n\nMost businesses handling dietary supplements whether manufacturing, packaging or selling will need to register their business either under a National Programme or with a Food Control plan. To find out more about this and other obligations under the Food Act 2014 visit the MPI website at:\u00a0 \u301070\u2020http://www.mpi.govt.nz/food-safety/food-act-2014/overview/\u2020www.mpi.govt.nz\u3011\n\nStep-by-step guides to registering a National Programme or Food Control Plan can be found on the relevant pages at: \u00a0\u301071\u2020https://www.mpi.govt.nz/food-safety/food-act-2014/\u2020www.mpi.govt.nz\u3011\n\n#### Requirements under the Biosecurity Act\n\nThe Ministry for Primary Industries is responsible for enforcing the Biosecurity Act 1993. The role of the Ministry for Primary Industries in managing potential biosecurity risks in dietary supplements and medical preparations is", "title": "Regulation of Dietary Supplements", "tether_id": null}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": null, "weight": 0.0, "metadata": {"_cite_metadata": {"citation_format": {"name": "tether_og"}, "metadata_list": [{"type": "webpage", "title": "Regulation of Dietary Supplements", "url": "https://www.medsafe.govt.nz/regulatory/DietarySupplements/Regulation.asp", "text": "  * have a stated or implied therapeutic purpose - the definition of a therapeutic purpose is given in the Medicines Act 1981.\n\n\u301062\u2020The Medsafe guideline on the Categorisation of Products can be used to determine whether a product is a dietary supplement\u3011.\n\n\u301063\u2020The Ministry for Primary Industries New Zealand Supplemented Food Standard \u2013 User Guide has a flow chart in chapter 4 which can help you decide whether your product is a dietary supplement or supplemented food.\u2020www.mpi.govt.nz\u3011\n\n* * *\n\n\u301061\u2020 \u3011\n\n#### Dietary Supplements containing Folic Acid\n\nThe maximum daily dose for a dietary supplement is 300 micrograms folic acid per day.\n\nHowever, the maximum daily dose of folic acid may be increased to 500 micrograms per day if the sponsor has demonstrated to Medsafe that the dietary supplement is manufactured in a Good Manufacturing Practice certified facility.\n\n\u301064\u2020Note that the Good Manufacturing Practice certification must meet the requirements specified in the Guideline for Therapeutic Products in New Zealand: Manufacture of Medicines\u3011 (PDF 136 KB, 9 pages).\n\nTo demonstrate that your product is manufactured in a Good Manufacturing Practice certified facility and to appropriate Good Manufacturing Practice standards you will need to:\n\n  1. \u301065\u2020Complete a declaration that the product is manufactured in a way that accords with the New Zealand Code of Good Manufacturing Practice using the Sponsor declaration form\u3011 (Microsoft Word document 50KB, 1 page)\n  2. \u301064\u2020Attach evidence of Good Manufacturing Practice compliance for the manufacturing site that is current, less than three years old and meets the requirements specified in the Guideline for Therapeutic products in New Zealand\u3011: Manufacture of Medicine (PDF 136 KB, 9 pages).\n  3. Send the completed declaration and Good Manufacturing Practice evidence to: dietarysupplements@health.govt.nz.  \n\nYou cannot legally supply dietary supplements containing more than 300 micrograms folic acid per daily dose until the Medsafe verified declaration has been returned to the sponsor. The verified declaration should be retained by the sponsor for at least one year after the expiry of the last batch supplied.\n\nIf Medsafe is not satisfied that all requirements are met the sponsor will be contacted.\n\nSponsor declarations are subject to audit. Medsafe reserves the right to request further details regarding the manufacturing arrangements and Good Manufacturing Practice compliance of the product while it remains on the market.\n\nA verified sponsor declaration remains valid if all details of the sponsor declaration remain unchanged. If changes are planned, the sponsor must submit an updated declaration and receive verification in advance of supplying the product to the New Zealand market.\n\nChanges that require a new declaration include (but are not limited to):\n\n  * sponsor details\n  * product name\n  * maximum daily dose\n  * manufacturing site\n  * packing site.\n\nIf the site manufacturing your product does not have acceptable Good Manufacturing Practice certification, you can contact the Compliance Management Branch of Medsafe to arrange a Good Manufacturing Practice audit. A service fee will apply to such audits in order to recover the time and travel costs associated with the audit.\n\nFor further information, contact the Compliance Management Branch on dietarysupplements@health.govt.nz.\n\n\u301066\u2020Questions and answers on requesting confirmation of GMP status for the manufacture of a dietary supplement containing folic acid with a daily dose of more than 300 mcg\u3011\n\n* * *\n\n\u301061\u2020 \u3011\n\n### Requirements under the Food Act\n\n#### Importing dietary supplements\n\nDietary supplements fall under the Food Act 2014. The Food Act requires import of all food for sale to be via a Registered Food Importer.\u00a0 If you are importing dietary supplements you must register as an importer with the Ministry for Primary Industries which has responsibility for administering the Food Act 2014.\n\nMPI lists registered food importers in a public database:\u00a0 See \u301067\u2020http://www.foodsafety.govt.nz/registers-lists/food-act-2014-registered-food-importers/index.htm\u2020www.foodsafety.govt.nz\u3011\n\n\u301068\u2020Information on how to register with the Ministry for Primary Industries is available on their website\u2020www.mpi.govt.nz\u3011 . There is a charge for registering as an importer.\n\n\u301069\u2020The New Zealand Customs Service is able to advise on the requirements (e.g., taxes, paperwork) for commercial importation into New Zealand\u2020www.customs.govt.nz\u3011.\n\nDietary supplements containing ingredients from animals and animal products are also subject to legislation set forth by the Biosecurity Act 1993. The biosecurity act legislation was enacted to protect New Zealand's environment, plants and animals from unwanted pests and diseases.\n\n* * *\n\n\u301061\u2020 \u3011\n\n#### Manufacturing and packing dietary supplements\n\nAs the Dietary Supplements Regulations 1985 fall under the Food Act 2014, dietary supplements should be manufactured, packed and sold in a manner that complies with the Food Act 2014 and the Food Regulations 2015.\n\nMost businesses handling dietary supplements whether manufacturing, packaging or selling will need to register their business either under a National Programme or with a Food Control plan. To find out more about this and other obligations under the Food Act 2014 visit the MPI website at:\u00a0 \u301070\u2020http://www.mpi.govt.nz/food-safety/food-act-2014/overview/\u2020www.mpi.govt.nz\u3011\n\nStep-by-step guides to registering a National Programme or Food Control Plan can be found on the relevant pages at: \u00a0\u301071\u2020https://www.mpi.govt.nz/food-safety/food-act-2014/\u2020www.mpi.govt.nz\u3011\n\n#### Requirements under the Biosecurity Act\n\nThe Ministry for Primary Industries is responsible for enforcing the Biosecurity Act 1993. The role of the Ministry for Primary Industries in managing potential biosecurity risks in dietary supplements and medical preparations is", "pub_date": null, "extra": null}], "original_query": null}, this\n\n\u30107\u2020Twitter\u2020twitter.com\u3011 \u30108\u2020Facebook\u2020facebook.com\u3011 \u30109\u2020Linkedin\u2020www.linkedin.com\u3011 Email\n\n18 February 2021\n\n#  Government extends dietary supplements regulations \n\nFood Safety \n\nThe Government is providing certainty for the dietary supplements industry as we work to overhaul the rules governing the products, Minister for Food Safety Dr Ayesha Verrall said.\n\nDietary supplements are health and wellness products taken orally to supplement a traditional diet. Some examples include vitamin and mineral supplements, echinacea, fish oils and probiotic tablets.\n\n\u201cThe dietary supplements industry is worth an estimated $2.3 billion to the economy and continues to grow,\u201d Dr Ayesha Verrall said. \n\n\u201cThe Food (Continuation of Dietary Supplements Regulations) Amendment Bill passed its third reading today.\u00a0We need modern regulations in place to keep pace with these changes in the products and consumers\u2019 expectations.\n\n\u201cWe've extended the current regulations for five years to ensure industry and consumers have certainty while we do this work. \n\n\u201cThis will mean our industry can continue to operate with certainty while new regulations are developed to consider all health and wellbeing products including traditional and herbal medicines.\n\n\u201cWe need regulations that will keep allowing for innovation while continuing to ensure the safety and suitability of products. \n\n\u201cA five-year extension of the Regulations is needed to allow consultation and development of new legislation, and a minimum two-year transition period,\u201d Dr Ayesha Verrall said. \n\n\u301010\u2020Top\u3011 \n\n## \u30108\u2020Facebook\u2020facebook.com\u3011 \u30109\u2020Linkedin\u2020www.linkedin.com\u3011 Email\n\n18 February 2021\n\n#  Government extends dietary supplements regulations \n\nFood Safety \n\nThe Government is providing certainty for the dietary supplements industry as we work to overhaul the rules governing the products, Minister for Food Safety Dr Ayesha Verrall said.\n\nDietary supplements are health and wellness products taken orally to supplement a traditional diet. Some examples include vitamin and mineral supplements, echinacea, fish oils and probiotic tablets.\n\n\u201cThe dietary supplements industry is worth an estimated $2.3 billion to the economy and continues to grow,\u201d Dr Ayesha Verrall said. \n\n\u201cThe Food (Continuation of Dietary Supplements Regulations) Amendment Bill passed its third reading today.\u00a0We need modern regulations in place to keep pace with these changes in the products and consumers\u2019 expectations.\n\n\u201cWe've extended the current regulations for five years to ensure industry and consumers have certainty while we do this work. \n\n\u201cThis will mean our industry can continue to operate with certainty while new regulations are developed to consider all health and wellbeing products including traditional and herbal medicines.\n\n\u201cWe need regulations that will keep allowing for innovation while continuing to ensure the safety and suitability of products. \n\n\u201cA five-year extension of the Regulations is needed to allow consultation and development of new legislation, and a minimum two-year transition period,\u201d Dr Ayesha Verrall said. \n\n\u301010\u2020Top\u3011 \n\n## Register \n\n  * Account & Access\n  * Sign in \n  * Register\n  * Sign out \n  * \u30104\u2020My account\u3011\n  * \u30103\u2020Subscribe\u3011\n\n# Welcome move: New Zealand health ministry plans to regulate supplements via self-assessment - Updated\n\nBy \u301092\u2020 By Tingmin Koe and Gary Scattergood \u3011 \n\n16-Aug-2022 - Last updated on 17-Oct-2022 at 03:32 GMT \n\n  * \u301093\u2020Facebook\u2020www.facebook.com\u3011 \n  * \u301094\u2020Twitter\u2020twitter.com\u3011\n  * \u301095\u2020Linkedin\u2020www.linkedin.com\u3011\n  * Email to a friend\n\n[Image 2: New Zealand\u2019s Ministry of Health is planning to regulate natural health products via a self-assessment / declaration process. \u00a9Getty Images ] New Zealand\u2019s Ministry of Health is planning to regulate natural health products via a self-assessment / declaration process. \u00a9Getty Images \n\nRelated tags \u301096\u2020Natural health products\u3011 \u301097\u2020New zealand\u3011 \u301098\u2020Export\u3011 \n\nNew Zealand\u2019s Ministry of Health is intending to regulate natural health products via a self-assessment / declaration process, a move welcomed by the local industry body. \n\nThe ministry has been working on drafting the Therapeutic Products Bill and recently announced the planned market authorisation process for therapeutic products.\n\nThere are five different processes drafted, of which, natural health products have been categorised under the self-assessment / declaration process.\n\nAccording to the announcement, the process is \u201can ongoing \u2018automatic assessment of information and authorisation carried out by a system\u201d and is applicable to natural health products, lowest-risk medical devices, and sunscreen.\n\nThe other four processes are 1) special access for enabling access to products in special circumstances, such as the treatment of life-threatening or rare disorder diseases, 2) provisional \u2013 a temporary authorisation which requires preliminary evidence of efficacy and safety, 3) standard (full) \u2013 a comprehensive evaluation for medium to high risk therapeutic products, and 4) standard (expedited) \u2013 a shorter version of full evaluation and requires evidence of overseas approvals issued by comparable regulators.\n\n\u201cThe Bill will enable the regulator to design flexible, risk-proportionate pathways for applicants to seek product approval. \n\n\u201cEach pathway will be designed to achieve an optimal level of regulatory oversight, taking into account the need to provide for patient safety and timely accessibility of products. \n\n\u201cThese pathways provide a framework that will address the specific nature of the product and the circumstances,\u201d said the MOH announcement.\n\nAt the same time, natural health products could be a non-prescription OTC therapeutic product, a pharmacist and pharmacy-only medicines, and foods and cosmetics.\n\nIn response, industry body Natural Health Products NZ (NHPNZ) welcomed the plan, commenting that this is the \u201conly logical risk and cost proportionate pathway for low-risk products such as natural health products.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe are encouraged to see in the MoH's diagrams clear recognition that N", "title": "New Zealand govt plans to regulate supplements via self-assessment", "tether_id": null}, Register \n\n  * Account & Access\n  * Sign in \n  * Register\n  * Sign out \n  * \u30104\u2020My account\u3011\n  * \u30103\u2020Subscribe\u3011\n\n# Welcome move: New Zealand health ministry plans to regulate supplements via self-assessment - Updated\n\nBy \u301092\u2020 By Tingmin Koe and Gary Scattergood \u3011 \n\n16-Aug-2022 - Last updated on 17-Oct-2022 at 03:32 GMT \n\n  * \u301093\u2020Facebook\u2020www.facebook.com\u3011 \n  * \u301094\u2020Twitter\u2020twitter.com\u3011\n  * \u301095\u2020Linkedin\u2020www.linkedin.com\u3011\n  * Email to a friend\n\n[Image 2: New Zealand\u2019s Ministry of Health is planning to regulate natural health products via a self-assessment / declaration process. \u00a9Getty Images ] New Zealand\u2019s Ministry of Health is planning to regulate natural health products via a self-assessment / declaration process. \u00a9Getty Images \n\nRelated tags \u301096\u2020Natural health products\u3011 \u301097\u2020New zealand\u3011 \u301098\u2020Export\u3011 \n\nNew Zealand\u2019s Ministry of Health is intending to regulate natural health products via a self-assessment / declaration process, a move welcomed by the local industry body. \n\nThe ministry has been working on drafting the Therapeutic Products Bill and recently announced the planned market authorisation process for therapeutic products.\n\nThere are five different processes drafted, of which, natural health products have been categorised under the self-assessment / declaration process.\n\nAccording to the announcement, the process is \u201can ongoing \u2018automatic assessment of information and authorisation carried out by a system\u201d and is applicable to natural health products, lowest-risk medical devices, and sunscreen.\n\nThe other four processes are 1) special access for enabling access to products in special circumstances, such as the treatment of life-threatening or rare disorder diseases, 2) provisional \u2013 a temporary authorisation which requires preliminary evidence of efficacy and safety, 3) standard (full) \u2013 a comprehensive evaluation for medium to high risk therapeutic products, and 4) standard (expedited) \u2013 a shorter version of full evaluation and requires evidence of overseas approvals issued by comparable regulators.\n\n\u201cThe Bill will enable the regulator to design flexible, risk-proportionate pathways for applicants to seek product approval. \n\n\u201cEach pathway will be designed to achieve an optimal level of regulatory oversight, taking into account the need to provide for patient safety and timely accessibility of products. \n\n\u201cThese pathways provide a framework that will address the specific nature of the product and the circumstances,\u201d said the MOH announcement.\n\nAt the same time, natural health products could be a non-prescription OTC therapeutic product, a pharmacist and pharmacy-only medicines, and foods and cosmetics.\n\nIn response, industry body Natural Health Products NZ (NHPNZ) welcomed the plan, commenting that this is the \u201conly logical risk and cost proportionate pathway for low-risk products such as natural health products.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe are encouraged to see in the MoH's diagrams clear recognition that N", "pub_date": null, "extra": null}], "original_query": null}, "command": "mclick", "args": ["[\"17\", \"14\", \"0\", \"6\", \"1\"]"], "status": "finished", "is_complete": true, "message_type": null, "model_slug": "gpt-4o", "default_model_slug": "auto", "parent_id": "8dca2983-1989-4139-936a-ccac30c14120", "request_id": "8b566eac6ce350ad-AKL", "timestamp_": "absolute"}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "8dca2983-1989-4139-936a-ccac30c14120", "children": ["c8b3d509-501e-4947-bc4d-27f64b797d85"]}, "c8b3d509-501e-4947-bc4d-27f64b797d85": {"id": "c8b3d509-501e-4947-bc4d-27f64b797d85", "message": {"id": "c8b3d509-501e-4947-bc4d-27f64b797d85", "author": {"role": "assistant", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1724031604.295701, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["In New Zealand, *Kanna* (Sceletium tortuosum) is regulated under the Dietary Supplements Regulations 1985, which have been extended under the Food Act 2014 as the government works on modernizing these laws. As of now, *Kanna* can be legally sold and used in supplements, provided it is labeled correctly and meets safety standards.\n\nRegarding its usage as an ingredient in other products, it falls under the category of natural health products and is considered low-risk. Therefore, its inclusion in products like dietary supplements is allowed, but it must comply with the standards set for dietary supplements, which include appropriate labeling and manufacturing practices.\n\nThere is no specific maximum dosage for *Kanna* outlined in the regulations, so it\u2019s important for manufacturers to adhere to general safety guidelines and to base dosage on scientific evidence. It's always best to consult with local authorities or a healthcare professional to ensure compliance with all current regulations.\n\nIf you plan to use or import *Kanna*, you'll need to follow the regulations under the Food Act 2014, including registration with the Ministry for Primary Industries if importing, and ensuring that the product meets the Good Manufacturing Practice standards if produced locally\u30109\u2020source\u3011\u301010\u2020source\u3011\u301011\u2020source\u3011."]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": true, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"citations": [{"start_ix": 1281, "end_ix": 1291, "citation_format_type": "tether_og", "metadata": {"type": "webpage", "title": "Regulation of Dietary Supplements", "url": "https://www.medsafe.govt.nz/regulatory/DietarySupplements/Regulation.asp", "text": "  * have a stated or implied therapeutic purpose - the definition of a therapeutic purpose is given in the Medicines Act 1981.\n\n\u301062\u2020The Medsafe guideline on the Categorisation of Products can be used to determine whether a product is a dietary supplement\u3011.\n\n\u301063\u2020The Ministry for Primary Industries New Zealand Supplemented Food Standard \u2013 User Guide has a flow chart in chapter 4 which can help you decide whether your product is a dietary supplement or supplemented food.\u2020www.mpi.govt.nz\u3011\n\n* * *\n\n\u301061\u2020 \u3011\n\n#### Dietary Supplements containing Folic Acid\n\nThe maximum daily dose for a dietary supplement is 300 micrograms folic acid per day.\n\nHowever, the maximum daily dose of folic acid may be increased to 500 micrograms per day if the sponsor has demonstrated to Medsafe that the dietary supplement is manufactured in a Good Manufacturing Practice certified facility.\n\n\u301064\u2020Note that the Good Manufacturing Practice certification must meet the requirements specified in the Guideline for Therapeutic Products in New Zealand: Manufacture of Medicines\u3011 (PDF 136 KB, 9 pages).\n\nTo demonstrate that your product is manufactured in a Good Manufacturing Practice certified facility and to appropriate Good Manufacturing Practice standards you will need to:\n\n  1. \u301065\u2020Complete a declaration that the product is manufactured in a way that accords with the New Zealand Code of Good Manufacturing Practice using the Sponsor declaration form\u3011 (Microsoft Word document 50KB, 1 page)\n  2. \u301064\u2020Attach evidence of Good Manufacturing Practice compliance for the manufacturing site that is current, less than three years old and meets the requirements specified in the Guideline for Therapeutic products in New Zealand\u3011: Manufacture of Medicine (PDF 136 KB, 9 pages).\n  3. Send the completed declaration and Good Manufacturing Practice evidence to: dietarysupplements@health.govt.nz.  \n\nYou cannot legally supply dietary supplements containing more than 300 micrograms folic acid per daily dose until the Medsafe verified declaration has been returned to the sponsor. The verified declaration should be retained by the sponsor for at least one year after the expiry of the last batch supplied.\n\nIf Medsafe is not satisfied that all requirements are met the sponsor will be contacted.\n\nSponsor declarations are subject to audit. Medsafe reserves the right to request further details regarding the manufacturing arrangements and Good Manufacturing Practice compliance of the product while it remains on the market.\n\nA verified sponsor declaration remains valid if all details of the sponsor declaration remain unchanged. If changes are planned, the sponsor must submit an updated declaration and receive verification in advance of supplying the product to the New Zealand market.\n\nChanges that require a new declaration include (but are not limited to):\n\n  * sponsor details\n  * product name\n  * maximum daily dose\n  * manufacturing site\n  * packing site.\n\nIf the site manufacturing your product does not have acceptable Good Manufacturing Practice certification, you can contact the Compliance Management Branch of Medsafe to arrange a Good Manufacturing Practice audit. A service fee will apply to such audits in order to recover the time and travel costs associated with the audit.\n\nFor further information, contact the Compliance Management Branch on dietarysupplements@health.govt.nz.\n\n\u301066\u2020Questions and answers on requesting confirmation of GMP status for the manufacture of a dietary supplement containing folic acid with a daily dose of more than 300 mcg\u3011\n\n* * *\n\n\u301061\u2020 \u3011\n\n### Requirements under the Food Act\n\n#### Importing dietary supplements\n\nDietary supplements fall under the Food Act 2014. The Food Act requires import of all food for sale to be via a Registered Food Importer.\u00a0 If you are importing dietary supplements you must register as an importer with the Ministry for Primary Industries which has responsibility for administering the Food Act 2014.\n\nMPI lists registered food importers in a public database:\u00a0 See \u301067\u2020http://www.foodsafety.govt.nz/registers-lists/food-act-2014-registered-food-importers/index.htm\u2020www.foodsafety.govt.nz\u3011\n\n\u301068\u2020Information on how to register with the Ministry for Primary Industries is available on their website\u2020www.mpi.govt.nz\u3011 . There is a charge for registering as an importer.\n\n\u301069\u2020The New Zealand Customs Service is able to advise on the requirements (e.g., taxes, paperwork) for commercial importation into New Zealand\u2020www.customs.govt.nz\u3011.\n\nDietary supplements containing ingredients from animals and animal products are also subject to legislation set forth by the Biosecurity Act 1993. The biosecurity act legislation was enacted to protect New Zealand's environment, plants and animals from unwanted pests and diseases.\n\n* * *\n\n\u301061\u2020 \u3011\n\n#### Manufacturing and packing dietary supplements\n\nAs the Dietary Supplements Regulations 1985 fall under the Food Act 2014, dietary supplements should be manufactured, packed and sold in a manner that complies with the Food Act 2014 and the Food Regulations 2015.\n\nMost businesses handling dietary supplements whether manufacturing, packaging or selling will need to register their business either under a National Programme or with a Food Control plan. To find out more about this and other obligations under the Food Act 2014 visit the MPI website at:\u00a0 \u301070\u2020http://www.mpi.govt.nz/food-safety/food-act-2014/overview/\u2020www.mpi.govt.nz\u3011\n\nStep-by-step guides to registering a National Programme or Food Control Plan can be found on the relevant pages at: \u00a0\u301071\u2020https://www.mpi.govt.nz/food-safety/food-act-2014/\u2020www.mpi.govt.nz\u3011\n\n#### Requirements under the Biosecurity Act\n\nThe Ministry for Primary Industries is responsible for enforcing the Biosecurity Act 1993. The role of the Ministry for Primary Industries in managing potential biosecurity risks in dietary supplements and medical preparations is", "pub_date": null, "extra": {"cited_message_idx": 9, February 2021\n\n#  Government extends dietary supplements regulations \n\nFood Safety \n\nThe Government is providing certainty for the dietary supplements industry as we work to overhaul the rules governing the products, Minister for Food Safety Dr Ayesha Verrall said.\n\nDietary supplements are health and wellness products taken orally to supplement a traditional diet. Some examples include vitamin and mineral supplements, echinacea, fish oils and probiotic tablets.\n\n\u201cThe dietary supplements industry is worth an estimated $2.3 billion to the economy and continues to grow,\u201d Dr Ayesha Verrall said. \n\n\u201cThe Food (Continuation of Dietary Supplements Regulations) Amendment Bill passed its third reading today.\u00a0We need modern regulations in place to keep pace with these changes in the products and consumers\u2019 expectations.\n\n\u201cWe've extended the current regulations for five years to ensure industry and consumers have certainty while we do this work. \n\n\u201cThis will mean our industry can continue to operate with certainty while new regulations are developed to consider all health and wellbeing products including traditional and herbal medicines.\n\n\u201cWe need regulations that will keep allowing for innovation while continuing to ensure the safety and suitability of products. \n\n\u201cA five-year extension of the Regulations is needed to allow consultation and development of new legislation, and a minimum two-year transition period,\u201d Dr Ayesha Verrall said. \n\n\u301010\u2020Top\u3011 \n\n## \u30104\u2020My account\u3011\n  * \u30103\u2020Subscribe\u3011\n\n# Welcome move: New Zealand health ministry plans to regulate supplements via self-assessment - Updated\n\nBy \u301092\u2020 By Tingmin Koe and Gary Scattergood \u3011 \n\n16-Aug-2022 - Last updated on 17-Oct-2022 at 03:32 GMT \n\n  * \u301093\u2020Facebook\u2020www.facebook.com\u3011 \n  * \u301094\u2020Twitter\u2020twitter.com\u3011\n  * \u301095\u2020Linkedin\u2020www.linkedin.com\u3011\n  * Email to a friend\n\n[Image 2: New Zealand\u2019s Ministry of Health is planning to regulate natural health products via a self-assessment / declaration process. \u00a9Getty Images ] New Zealand\u2019s Ministry of Health is planning to regulate natural health products via a self-assessment / declaration process. \u00a9Getty Images \n\nRelated tags \u301096\u2020Natural health products\u3011 \u301097\u2020New zealand\u3011 \u301098\u2020Export\u3011 \n\nNew Zealand\u2019s Ministry of Health is intending to regulate natural health products via a self-assessment / declaration process, a move welcomed by the local industry body. \n\nThe ministry has been working on drafting the Therapeutic Products Bill and recently announced the planned market authorisation process for therapeutic products.\n\nThere are five different processes drafted, of which, natural health products have been categorised under the self-assessment / declaration process.\n\nAccording to the announcement, the process is \u201can ongoing \u2018automatic assessment of information and authorisation carried out by a system\u201d and is applicable to natural health products, lowest-risk medical devices, and sunscreen.\n\nThe other four processes are 1) special access for enabling access to products in special circumstances, such as the treatment of life-threatening or rare disorder diseases, 2) provisional \u2013 a temporary authorisation which requires preliminary evidence of efficacy and safety, 3) standard (full) \u2013 a comprehensive evaluation for medium to high risk therapeutic products, and 4) standard (expedited) \u2013 a shorter version of full evaluation and requires evidence of overseas approvals issued by comparable regulators.\n\n\u201cThe Bill will enable the regulator to design flexible, risk-proportionate pathways for applicants to seek product approval. \n\n\u201cEach pathway will be designed to achieve an optimal level of regulatory oversight, taking into account the need to provide for patient safety and timely accessibility of products. \n\n\u201cThese pathways provide a framework that will address the specific nature of the product and the circumstances,\u201d said the MOH announcement.\n\nAt the same time, natural health products could be a non-prescription OTC therapeutic product, a pharmacist and pharmacy-only medicines, and foods and cosmetics.\n\nIn response, industry body Natural Health Products NZ (NHPNZ) welcomed the plan, commenting that this is the \u201conly logical risk and cost proportionate pathway for low-risk products such as natural health products.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe are encouraged to see in the MoH's diagrams clear recognition that N", "pub_date": null, "extra": {"cited_message_idx": 11, "search_result_idx": null, "evidence_text": "source", "cloud_doc_url": null}}}], "content_references": [{"matched_text": "\u30109\u2020source\u3011", "start_idx": 1281, "end_idx": 1291, "alt": null, "type": "webpage_extended", "title": "Regulation of Dietary Supplements", "url": "https://www.medsafe.govt.nz/regulatory/DietarySupplements/Regulation.asp", "pub_date": null, "snippet": "  * have a stated or implied therapeutic purpose - the definition of a therapeutic purpose is given in the Medicines Act 1981.\n\n\u301062\u2020The Medsafe guideline on the Categorisation of Products can be used to determine whether a product is a dietary supplement\u3011.\n\n\u301063\u2020The Ministry for Primary Industries New Zealand Supplemented Food Standard \u2013 User Guide has a flow chart in chapter 4 which can help you decide whether your product is a dietary supplement or supplemented food.\u2020www.mpi.govt.nz\u3011\n\n* * *\n\n\u301061\u2020 \u3011\n\n#### Dietary Supplements containing Folic Acid\n\nThe maximum daily dose for a dietary supplement is 300 micrograms folic acid per day.\n\nHowever, the maximum daily dose of folic acid may be increased to 500 micrograms per day if the sponsor has demonstrated to Medsafe that the dietary supplement is manufactured in a Good Manufacturing Practice certified facility.\n\n\u301064\u2020Note that the Good Manufacturing Practice certification must meet the requirements specified in the Guideline for Therapeutic Products in New Zealand: Manufacture of Medicines\u3011 (PDF 136 KB, 9 pages).\n\nTo demonstrate that your product is manufactured in a Good Manufacturing Practice certified facility and to appropriate Good Manufacturing Practice standards you will need to:\n\n  1. \u301065\u2020Complete a declaration that the product is manufactured in a way that accords with the New Zealand Code of Good Manufacturing Practice using the Sponsor declaration form\u3011 (Microsoft Word document 50KB, 1 page)\n  2. \u301064\u2020Attach evidence of Good Manufacturing Practice compliance for the manufacturing site that is current, less than three years old and meets the requirements specified in the Guideline for Therapeutic products in New Zealand\u3011: Manufacture of Medicine (PDF 136 KB, 9 pages).\n  3. Send the completed declaration and Good Manufacturing Practice evidence to: dietarysupplements@health.govt.nz.  \n\nYou cannot legally supply dietary supplements containing more than 300 micrograms folic acid per daily dose until the Medsafe verified declaration has been returned to the sponsor. The verified declaration should be retained by the sponsor for at least one year after the expiry of the last batch supplied.\n\nIf Medsafe is not satisfied that all requirements are met the sponsor will be contacted.\n\nSponsor declarations are subject to audit. Medsafe reserves the right to request further details regarding the manufacturing arrangements and Good Manufacturing Practice compliance of the product while it remains on the market.\n\nA verified sponsor declaration remains valid if all details of the sponsor declaration remain unchanged. If changes are planned, the sponsor must submit an updated declaration and receive verification in advance of supplying the product to the New Zealand market.\n\nChanges that require a new declaration include (but are not limited to):\n\n  * sponsor details\n  * product name\n  * maximum daily dose\n  * manufacturing site\n  * packing site.\n\nIf the site manufacturing your product does not have acceptable Good Manufacturing Practice certification, you can contact the Compliance Management Branch of Medsafe to arrange a Good Manufacturing Practice audit. A service fee will apply to such audits in order to recover the time and travel costs associated with the audit.\n\nFor further information, contact the Compliance Management Branch on dietarysupplements@health.govt.nz.\n\n\u301066\u2020Questions and answers on requesting confirmation of GMP status for the manufacture of a dietary supplement containing folic acid with a daily dose of more than 300 mcg\u3011\n\n* * *\n\n\u301061\u2020 \u3011\n\n### Requirements under the Food Act\n\n#### Importing dietary supplements\n\nDietary supplements fall under the Food Act 2014. The Food Act requires import of all food for sale to be via a Registered Food Importer.\u00a0 If you are importing dietary supplements you must register as an importer with the Ministry for Primary Industries which has responsibility for administering the Food Act 2014.\n\nMPI lists registered food importers in a public database:\u00a0 See \u301067\u2020http://www.foodsafety.govt.nz/registers-lists/food-act-2014-registered-food-importers/index.htm\u2020www.foodsafety.govt.nz\u3011\n\n\u301068\u2020Information on how to register with the Ministry for Primary Industries is available on their website\u2020www.mpi.govt.nz\u3011 . There is a charge for registering as an importer.\n\n\u301069\u2020The New Zealand Customs Service is able to advise on the requirements (e.g., taxes, paperwork) for commercial importation into New Zealand\u2020www.customs.govt.nz\u3011.\n\nDietary supplements containing ingredients from animals and animal products are also subject to legislation set forth by the Biosecurity Act 1993. The biosecurity act legislation was enacted to protect New Zealand's environment, plants and animals from unwanted pests and diseases.\n\n* * *\n\n\u301061\u2020 \u3011\n\n#### Manufacturing and packing dietary supplements\n\nAs the Dietary Supplements Regulations 1985 fall under the Food Act 2014, dietary supplements should be manufactured, packed and sold in a manner that complies with the Food Act 2014 and the Food Regulations 2015.\n\nMost businesses handling dietary supplements whether manufacturing, packaging or selling will need to register their business either under a National Programme or with a Food Control plan. To find out more about this and other obligations under the Food Act 2014 visit the MPI website at:\u00a0 \u301070\u2020http://www.mpi.govt.nz/food-safety/food-act-2014/overview/\u2020www.mpi.govt.nz\u3011\n\nStep-by-step guides to registering a National Programme or Food Control Plan can be found on the relevant pages at: \u00a0\u301071\u2020https://www.mpi.govt.nz/food-safety/food-act-2014/\u2020www.mpi.govt.nz\u3011\n\n#### Requirements under the Biosecurity Act\n\nThe Ministry for Primary Industries is responsible for enforcing the Biosecurity Act 1993. The role of the Ministry for Primary Industries in managing potential biosecurity risks in dietary supplements and medical preparations is"}, {"matched_text": "\u301010\u2020source\u3011", this\n\n\u30107\u2020Twitter\u2020twitter.com\u3011 \u30108\u2020Facebook\u2020facebook.com\u3011 \u30109\u2020Linkedin\u2020www.linkedin.com\u3011 Email\n\n18 February 2021\n\n#  Government extends dietary supplements regulations \n\nFood Safety \n\nThe Government is providing certainty for the dietary supplements industry as we work to overhaul the rules governing the products, Minister for Food Safety Dr Ayesha Verrall said.\n\nDietary supplements are health and wellness products taken orally to supplement a traditional diet. Some examples include vitamin and mineral supplements, echinacea, fish oils and probiotic tablets.\n\n\u201cThe dietary supplements industry is worth an estimated $2.3 billion to the economy and continues to grow,\u201d Dr Ayesha Verrall said. \n\n\u201cThe Food (Continuation of Dietary Supplements Regulations) Amendment Bill passed its third reading today.\u00a0We need modern regulations in place to keep pace with these changes in the products and consumers\u2019 expectations.\n\n\u201cWe've extended the current regulations for five years to ensure industry and consumers have certainty while we do this work. \n\n\u201cThis will mean our industry can continue to operate with certainty while new regulations are developed to consider all health and wellbeing products including traditional and herbal medicines.\n\n\u201cWe need regulations that will keep allowing for innovation while continuing to ensure the safety and suitability of products. \n\n\u201cA five-year extension of the Regulations is needed to allow consultation and development of new legislation, and a minimum two-year transition period,\u201d Dr Ayesha Verrall said. \n\n\u301010\u2020Top\u3011 \n\n## to regulate supplements via self-assessment - Updated\n\nBy \u301092\u2020 By Tingmin Koe and Gary Scattergood \u3011 \n\n16-Aug-2022 - Last updated on 17-Oct-2022 at 03:32 GMT \n\n  * \u301093\u2020Facebook\u2020www.facebook.com\u3011 \n  * \u301094\u2020Twitter\u2020twitter.com\u3011\n  * \u301095\u2020Linkedin\u2020www.linkedin.com\u3011\n  * Email to a friend\n\n[Image 2: New Zealand\u2019s Ministry of Health is planning to regulate natural health products via a self-assessment / declaration process. \u00a9Getty Images ] New Zealand\u2019s Ministry of Health is planning to regulate natural health products via a self-assessment / declaration process. \u00a9Getty Images \n\nRelated tags \u301096\u2020Natural health products\u3011 \u301097\u2020New zealand\u3011 \u301098\u2020Export\u3011 \n\nNew Zealand\u2019s Ministry of Health is intending to regulate natural health products via a self-assessment / declaration process, a move welcomed by the local industry body. \n\nThe ministry has been working on drafting the Therapeutic Products Bill and recently announced the planned market authorisation process for therapeutic products.\n\nThere are five different processes drafted, of which, natural health products have been categorised under the self-assessment / declaration process.\n\nAccording to the announcement, the process is \u201can ongoing \u2018automatic assessment of information and authorisation carried out by a system\u201d and is applicable to natural health products, lowest-risk medical devices, and sunscreen.\n\nThe other four processes are 1) special access for enabling access to products in special circumstances, such as the treatment of life-threatening or rare disorder diseases, 2) provisional \u2013 a temporary authorisation which requires preliminary evidence of efficacy and safety, 3) standard (full) \u2013 a comprehensive evaluation for medium to high risk therapeutic products, and 4) standard (expedited) \u2013 a shorter version of full evaluation and requires evidence of overseas approvals issued by comparable regulators.\n\n\u201cThe Bill will enable the regulator to design flexible, risk-proportionate pathways for applicants to seek product approval. \n\n\u201cEach pathway will be designed to achieve an optimal level of regulatory oversight, taking into account the need to provide for patient safety and timely accessibility of products. \n\n\u201cThese pathways provide a framework that will address the specific nature of the product and the circumstances,\u201d said the MOH announcement.\n\nAt the same time, natural health products could be a non-prescription OTC therapeutic product, a pharmacist and pharmacy-only medicines, and foods and cosmetics.\n\nIn response, industry body Natural Health Products NZ (NHPNZ) welcomed the plan, commenting that this is the \u201conly logical risk and cost proportionate pathway for low-risk products such as natural health products.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe are encouraged to see in the MoH's diagrams clear recognition that N"}], "gizmo_id": null, "message_type": null, "model_slug": "gpt-4o", "default_model_slug": "auto", "parts": ["The typical recreational dose of *Kanna* varies depending on the form and intended effects:\n\n1. **Raw Powder**: A common recreational dose ranges from **100 mg to 1 gram**. Lower doses are generally used for mild mood enhancement, while higher doses are aimed at achieving more noticeable euphoria or relaxation.\n\n2. **Standardized Extract**: For extracts, the dose is typically lower, around **50 mg to 200 mg**. These doses can offer significant effects due to the concentrated alkaloids.\n\n3. **Chewing or Sublingual Use**: When chewing the raw plant or using it sublingually, doses around **100 mg to 500 mg** are common. This method is believed to produce faster effects.\n\nAlways start with the lower end of the dosing range to gauge your tolerance, as individual reactions can vary widely. Keep in mind that higher doses can lead to overstimulation or other unwanted side effects."]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": true, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"citations": [], "content_references": [], "gizmo_id": null, "finish_details": {"type": "stop", "stop_tokens": [200002]}, "is_complete": true, "message_type": null, "model_slug": "gpt-4o", "default_model_slug": "auto", "pad": "AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA", "parent_id": "aaa2b66a-33ec-412d-82d2-e0007addee43", "request_id": "8b56730dea9c50ae-AKL", "timestamp_": "absolute"}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "aaa2b66a-33ec-412d-82d2-e0007addee43", "children": ["aaa27539-ae8d-4cf7-92fa-23be4ee26d0c"]}, "aaa27539-ae8d-4cf7-92fa-23be4ee26d0c": {"id": "aaa27539-ae8d-4cf7-92fa-23be4ee26d0c", "message": {"id": "aaa27539-ae8d-4cf7-92fa-23be4ee26d0c", "author": {"role": "user", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1724031827.562493, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["price point vs other dietary supplements in general"]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": null, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"request_id": "8b567467b9c050ae-AKL", "message_source": null, "timestamp_": "absolute", "message_type": null}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "1ea03c62-3472-432d-a397-a370e829ec95", "children": ["8adf75cb-ec8c-453d-977e-9f9b66d5cab2"]}, "8adf75cb-ec8c-453d-977e-9f9b66d5cab2": {"id": "8adf75cb-ec8c-453d-977e-9f9b66d5cab2", "message": {"id": "8adf75cb-ec8c-453d-977e-9f9b66d5cab2", "author": {"role": "assistant", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1724031835.233564, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["*Kanna* supplements are generally priced higher than more common dietary supplements like vitamins or minerals due to its niche status and the complexity of its production. The price can vary significantly depending on the form (raw powder, extract, capsule) and the concentration of active ingredients.\n\n- **Raw Powder**: Typically priced at **$20 to $40** per 50 grams, depending on quality.\n- **Standardized Extracts**: These are more expensive, usually costing **$30 to $60** for a small bottle or around 30 doses.\n- **Capsules**: Depending on the potency and brand, a bottle of 30 capsules can range from **$20 to $50**.\n\nIn comparison, common dietary supplements like Vitamin C or fish oil tend to be more affordable. For example, a 60-count bottle of Vitamin C may cost around **$10 to $15**, and a similar quantity of fish oil might be **$15 to $25**.\n\nThe higher cost of *Kanna* is primarily due to its specialized use, lower market demand, and the specific sourcing and preparation methods involved."]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": true, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"citations": [],
