2: New Zealand China Council] \n\n\u30100\u2020 \u3011 \n\n English \u30101\u2020 \u2020twitter.com\u3011 \u30102\u2020 \u2020www.linkedin.com\u3011 \u30103\u2020 \u2020www.instagram.com\u3011 \u30104\u2020 \u2020www.youtube.com\u3011 \n\n  * \u30105\u2020Home\u3011 \n    * \u30106\u2020News\u3011 \n  * The Council \n    * \u30107\u2020About\u3011 \n    * \u30108\u2020Our People\u3011 \n    * \u30109\u2020Strategic Plan\u3011 \n  * Initiatives \n    * \u301010\u2020Publications\u3011 \n    * \u301011\u2020Building The Southern Link\u3011 \n    * \u301012\u20202024 China Media Visit\u3011 \n  * \u301013\u2020Statistics\u3011 \n  * \u301014\u2020Podcasts\u3011 \n  * \u301015\u2020Insight\u3011 \n  * \u301016\u2020Events\u3011 \n    * \u301016\u2020Upcoming Events\u3011 \n    * \u301017\u2020Past Events\u3011 \n    * \u301018\u2020Event Galleries\u3011 \n  * \u301019\u2020Contact\u3011 \n\n# Statistics\n\nThe New Zealand China Council NZ China Dashboard provides key statistics about the bilateral relationship:\n\n  * Trade flows between New Zealand and China\n  * Imports and exports of key commodities\n  * Investment flows between New Zealand and China\n  * Education\n  * Tourism\n  * Chinese language acquisition in New Zealand\n\nThe following interactive charts put New Zealand\u2019s relationship with China into perspective against other major partners.\n\n## New Zealand's Goods Exports: Top Markets (NZ$b per year)\n\nNew Zealand exported over NZ$18 billion worth of goods to China (year to December 2023), over double that of our next biggest export markets the US (NZ$8 billion) and Australia (NZ$7.8 billion).\n\nSource \u2013 Stats NZ\n\n## New Zealand's Goods Imports: Top Sources (NZ$b per year)\n\nChina remains our largest source of imported goods, at over NZ$16b (year to December 2023), followed by Australia (NZ$8.4 billion), USA (NZ$7.6 billion), South Korea and Japan.\n\nSource \u2013 Stats NZ\n\n## New Zealand's Share of China's Goods Imports: Top 10 (2023)\n\nNZ supplies more than half the dairy products that China imports from the world. New Zealand also supplies a significant amount of the wood, meat and fruit that China imports.\n\nSource \u2013 Global Trade Atlas\n\n## China's Share of New Zealand's Goods Imports: Top 10 (2023)\n\nMany of the goods that New Zealand imports are supplied primarily by China, such as clothing, toys and games and furniture.\n\nSource \u2013 Global Trade Atlas\n\n## Foreign Investment in New Zealand (Stock of FDI, NZ$m) \n\nForeign investment from China, including Hong Kong reached $9.2b (year to March 2023).\u00a0 This is well below our largest investor, Australia (at $78b), and is relatively low considering the size of the trade relationship, people to people links and other connections.\n\nSource \u2013 Stats NZ\n\n## International Fee Paying Students in New Zealand \n\nIn 2023 China was the largest source economy for international students enrolled at NZ education institutions, at 23,907 students (35% of total enrolments). Sub-sector totals for Chinese students in 2023: universities 14,675, schools 4,271, Te P\u016bkenga 2,135, private training establishments (PTEs) 2023, English language schools 951.\u00a0 India was the second largest source country at 11.5 per cent, Japan at 10 per cent.\n\nSource \u2013\u00a0\u301020\u2020https://public.tableau.com/app/profile/education.new.zealand/viz/MOEInternationalStudentEnrolments2013to2023FinalChange/BarCharts-InternationalEnrolments2013-2023\u2020public.tableau.com\u3011\n\n## Visitor Numbers to New Zealand: Top Sources \n\nPrior to COVID (2019) China was New Zealand\u2019s second largest source of visitors behind Australia. In January 2024 it ranked 3rd with 158,000 visitors (Australia 505,000, US 317,000).\u00a0 But further market recovery is expected now that borders have re-opened.\n\nSource \u2013 Stats NZ\n\n## NZ Secondary Students Learning a Foreign Language \n\nThe number of secondary level students learning Chinese in New Zealand has increased slightly in 2023 but remains below the number studying French, Japanese and Spanish.\n\nSource \u2013\u00a0https://www.educationcounts.govt.nz/statistics/subject-enrolment\n\n## NZ Primary Students Learning a Foreign Language\n\nThere has been a big increase in the number of primary level students learning Chinese in New Zealand in recent years, with nearly 65,000 primary students currently studying Chinese.\n\n## Subscribe to Updates\n\nGet the latest email updates\n\nName: \n\nEmail: \n\n## LinkedIn \u30102\u2020Latest Updates\u2020www.linkedin.com\u3011\n\n## Upcoming Events\n\n#### September 2024\n\n\u301021\u202022\u3011 \n\n\u301021\u20202024 New Zealand Chinese Language Week - 22nd September\u3011 \u301021\u202022 \u2013 28 SEPTEMBER 2024 New Zealand Chinese Language\u2026\u3011 \n\n  * \u30105\u2020Home\u3011 \n    * \u30106\u2020News\u3011 \n  * The Council \n    * \u30107\u2020About\u3011 \n    * \u30108\u2020Our People\u3011 \n    * \u30109\u2020Strategic Plan\u3011 \n  * Initiatives \n    * \u301010\u2020Publications\u3011 \n    * \u301011\u2020Building The Southern Link\u3011 \n    * \u301012\u20202024 China Media Visit\u3011 \n  * \u301013\u2020Statistics\u3011 \n  * \u301014\u2020Podcasts\u3011 \n  * \u301015\u2020Insight\u3011 \n  * \u301016\u2020Events\u3011 \n    * \u301016\u2020Upcoming Events\u3011 \n    * \u301017\u2020Past Events\u3011 \n    * \u301018\u2020Event Galleries\u3011 \n  * \u301019\u2020Contact\u3011 \n\n MENU \n\n X \n\n[Image 3][Image 4]\n\n", "pub_date": null, "extra": {"cited_message_idx": 8, "search_result_idx": null, "evidence_text": "source", "cloud_doc_url": null}}}, {"start_ix": 466, "end_ix": 476, "citation_format_type": "tether_og", "metadata": {"type": "webpage", "title": "NZ economic performance in 2022, and future prospects | New Zealand Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade", "url": "https://www.mfat.govt.nz/en/trade/mfat-market-reports/nz-economic-performance-in-2022-and-future-prospects", "text": "  * \u301090\u2020 Follow us \u3011 \n\n# NZ economic performance in 2022, and future prospects\n\n  1. \u301091\u2020Home\u3011\n  2. \u301025\u2020Trade\u3011\n  3. \u301029\u2020MFAT Market Intelligence Reports\u3011\n  4. \u301092\u2020NZ economic performance in 2022, and future prospects\u3011\n\n\u301029\u2020Back to MFAT Market Intelligence Reports\u3011\n\nWeekly Global Report, Food and Beverage, Primary Products, Services: March 2023\n\nOn this page\n\n## Summary\n\n  * New\u00a0Zealand\u2019s two-way trade grew solidly in 2022 as global and domestic demand showed surprising resilience in the face of slowing global growth, rising inflation, and tightening credit conditions. The value of trade was also underpinned by an increase in global inflation to 8.8%, which supported the incomes of exporters but also added to the cost of imports.\n  * New\u00a0Zealand\u2019s two-way trade value now sits at $197.0 billion, growing by 21% year on year. Total exports (goods and services) grew by 16% to $89.9 billion, while total imports grew by 25% to $107.1 billion.\n  * Goods exports grew 13% to $72.0 billion for the year ending December 2022, while goods imports grew 21% to $80.1 billion.\n  * Driven by the removal of COVID-19 restrictions, services exports are continuing their recovery, rising 28% to $17.9 billion and services imports rising 38% to $26.9 billion.\n  * This recovery is in the face of significant international headwinds. In particular, Russia\u2019s war on Ukraine exacerbated inflationary pressures and weighed heavily on growth prospects for a global economy that was still recovering from the effects of COVID-19. This will further delay the likelihood of a return to pre-pandemic global economic growth.\n  * However, with China\u2019s easing of its zero-COVID policy, supply chain pressures cooling, and oil prices falling, we can expect some of these international pressures to ease in the coming year and for the weakness in global economic growth to bottom out.\n  * Nevertheless, Cyclone Gabrielle has delivered a shock to our key exporting regions. The economic effects, although yet are to be quantified, will be significant for some export sectors, especially apples.\n\n## Report \n\nThe closing of 2022 saw the New\u00a0Zealand economy running hot, with household spending remaining strong and businesses continuing to hire staff, which has contributed to low unemployment and rising wages.\n\nThis has been reflected in the 21% rise in the value of New\u00a0Zealand\u2019s two-way trade during 2022, increasing to $197.0 billion compared with the previous year.\u00a0 Total exports rose 16% to $89.9 billion, while imports rose 25% to $107.1 billion. (See Figure 1)\n\n##### Figure 1: New\u00a0Zealand\u2019s total trade performance (2019 \u2013 2022)\n\n[Image 1: Figure 1: New Zealand\u2019s total trade performance 2019 \u2013 2022. ]  Figure 1: New Zealand\u2019s total trade performance (2019 \u2013 2022) \n\n### Two-way trade remained strong in 2022 \n\nIn the year ended December 2022 New Zealand\u2019s total goods exports grew by 13% to $72 billion, and now sits 20% above pre-pandemic levels.\n\nDespite the challenges faced by the farming sector in 2022 (i.e. labour shortages, supply chain disruptions, global inflationary pressures), New Zealand\u2019s food exports have continued to perform impressively. Dairy products remained one of our best performing export sectors, boosted by strong prices and favourable exchange rates. Exports of milk powder, butter, and cheese rose 20%, along with casein products up 44%. Wine exports rose 14% thanks to a strong harvest and improved prices. Meat exports rose 12%, benefitting from increased demand for beef imports from China over the first three quarters of the year. Seafood exports rose by 8%, while crude oil exports doubled in value in 2022 to $913 million as the war in Ukraine led to significant price spikes in May. Aluminium exports continue to rise, owing to increasing worldwide aluminium prices, up 15% and now at $1.65 billion. (see Figure 2)\n\nFruit and wood exports, on the other hand, have seen declines of 2% and 5% respectively. The horticulture sector saw mixed results over 2022, with lower production, higher shipping costs, and labour availability affecting the sector\u2019s export revenue. Kiwifruit exports suffered the most due to a tough growing season, falling 5% to $2.6 billion. Avocado also struggled, falling to $81.6 million (down 27%) as price weaknesses affected returns, influenced by increased volumes in the global market from Australia. Conversely, apple exports rose 6% to $901.5 million in the same period. Forestry exports, in particular logs, suffered largely in part due to China\u2019s softening construction activity. Medical equipment exports fell 17% from $1.4 billion to $1.2 billion as COVID-19 demand reduced alongside persistent supply logistics constraints. (See Figure 2)\n\n##### Figure 2: Change in Goods Exports (Year ended December 2022)\n\n[Image 2: Figure 2: Change in Goods Exports Year ended December 2022. ]  Figure 2: Change in Goods Exports (Year ended December 2022) \n\nThe growth in goods exports was supported by increased trade with a range of partners (particularly Australia, the US, Japan, Korea and Indonesia). Due to lockdown measures, export growth to China slowed significantly over the year, from 16% in 2021 to just 1% in 2022. Despite not contributing substantially t", "pub_date": null, "extra": {"cited_message_idx": 9, "search_result_idx": null, "evidence_text": "source", "cloud_doc_url": null}}}], "gizmo_id": null, "finish_details": {"type": "stop", "stop_tokens": [200002]}, "is_complete": true, "message_type": null, "model_slug": "gpt-4o", "default_model_slug": "auto", "pad": "AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA", "parent_id": "7d244ed6-a3fd-4e93-94d9-c72bf56d7e13", "request_id": "8aebc9884a8e7257-AKL", "timestamp_": "absolute", "content_references": [{"matched_text": "\u30107\u2020source\u3011", "start_idx": 285, "end_idx": 295, "alt": null, "type": "webpage_extended", "title": "China: An economy of two speeds - July 2024 | New Zealand Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade", "url": "https://www.mfat.govt.nz/en/trade/mfat-market-reports/china-an-economy-of-two-speeds-july-2024", "pub_date": null, "snippet": "\n#### \u2026 but a two-speed economy has emerged\n\nHowever economic data from the first five months of 2024 points to an economy operating at two speeds: manufacturing activity and exports racing ahead, as domestic consumption and the property market remains stalled. \u00a0China\u2019s retail growth remained below pre-pandemic projections, 2.3% yoy in April, the slowest rate since 2022, although there was an improvement in May (3.7% yoy). Automobile sales revenue saw a decline of 5.6% yoy in April, due to intense competition in the domestic market. Sales of EVs by volume was up by 4% yoy in April, but lower car prices caused overall sales value to fall by 5.6% yoy. However, in May domestic EV purchases by value picked up with a 4.4% yoy decrease (an improvement on April\u2019s 5.6% drop). Commentators attribute this to consumers making the most of government subsidies for replacing old cars for newer models.\n\nThe property sector downturn continued, with property sales declining 20.7% yoy in May, after a 22.8% yoy drop in April. \u00a0Investment in property also fell 10.1% yoy in the year to May. Looking at commercial property, both the total sales and floor space of new commercial building were down 28% yoy and 20% yoy respectively over the January \u2013 May period. There is broad consensus amongst analysts that the property sector remains the most significant drag on China\u2019s economic activity.\n\n#### Tourism: number of trips up; spend per person down\n\nDuring the Dragon Boat Festival three-day weekend (June 8-10) total travel spending performed strongly. According to official data, 110 million domestic trips (in China) were made by Chinese tourists over the holiday period, up 6.3% yoy and 14.6% higher than the same period in 2019. Total consumer spending notched an 8.1% yoy increase and a 2.6% increase on 2019 levels. However, behind the increase in total spending, there has been a drop in individual spend, down 12.3% on 2019 according to Citigroup analysts.\n\nThe discrepancy between the increase in number of trips and the drop in per head spending was also evident during other Chinese holidays earlier in the year (e.g. Spring Festival in February and Labour Day in May). Analysts have attributed this to the changing behaviour of Chinese tourists, who are now opting for shorter and cheaper trips, amid more gloomy economic conditions.\n\n#### Incremental shift away from deflation\u00a0\n\nChina\u2019s inflation has ticked upwards in the month of May to 0.3%, the third consecutive monthly increase, indicating a move away from deflation. The low price of pork (which plays a significant role in calculating China\u2019s CPI), is anticipated to increase over the short-to-medium term as Chinese farmers limit pork supply for the upcoming season, so this will add further upward pressure to China\u2019s inflation rate. The Producer\u2019s Price Index (PPI) \u2013 a measure of the factory gate price of goods \u2013 showed that prices fell in the month of May, but the drop was the smallest drop in 2024. Simply put, prices were falling by less and less each month. The improvement was spurred by a rally in major commodity prices and last year\u2019s low base. Analysts have interpreted the increase in inflation (observed in both the CPI and PPI) as a positive sign, but the current national inflation rate of 0.3% remains far below the government target of 3%, so the fight for higher inflation remains ongoing.\n\n#### Trade friction continues\n\nGeopolitics threatens to dampen Chinese exports as third country concerns over the country\u2019s overcapacity increase. Critics argue China\u2019s industrial policy has supported the creation of significant production capacity in a number of green technologies (namely EVs, solar panels, and batteries). Critics have furthermore argued that China\u2019s overcapacity allows Chinese manufacturers to export their products at prices that undercut existing competitors, and by extension hampers the development (or even threatens the survival) of those industries overseas. China contends that existing competitors should instead focus on improving their competitiveness. Economists point out that many economies export more than they import (e.g. Germany exports 80% of its automobiles, the US 80% of its semiconductors), but what makes China\u2019s overcapacity unique is the absolute scale of China\u2019s trade and production capacity.\u00a0\n\nIn response to these concerns, a number of countries have announced restrictions on Chinese imports. \u00a0On May 14 the US announced upgraded tariffs on a range of Chinese imports, the highest profile being the increase in tariffs on electric vehicles from 25% to 100%. On June 13, the European Union followed suit with their own tariffs on Chinese EVs of between 17% and 38%, which would add to the existing 10% import duty on foreign-made cars. Most recently, on June 29, Canada\u2019s Ministry of Finance launched a 30-day consultation on the imposition of a surtax on Chinese EVs.\n\n#### Inbound foreign direct investment remains subdued\n\nChina\u2019s inbound foreign direct investment (FDI) fell 27.9% yoy in the year to April 2024 to 360 billion yuan (NZ$80 billion). FDI in April totalled 58.8 billion yuan (NZ$13 billion), the lowest figure since November 2023. A challenging macroeconomic environment, weak domestic consumption, and tense geopolitics are cited by analysts for the drop in FDI. \u00a0\n\n#### Policy support for the property sector\n\nOn May 17 China\u2019s central government announced a nationwide programme to provide 300 billion yuan (NZ $67 billion) in loans to fund state purchases of unsold h"}, {"matched_text": 22nd September\u3011 \u301021\u202022 \u2013 28 SEPTEMBER 2024 New Zealand Chinese Language\u2026\u3011 \n\n  * \u30105\u2020Home\u3011 \n    * \u30106\u2020News\u3011 \n  * The Council \n    * \u30107\u2020About\u3011 \n    * \u30108\u2020Our People\u3011 \n    * \u30109\u2020Strategic Plan\u3011 \n  * Initiatives \n    * \u301010\u2020Publications\u3011 \n    * \u301011\u2020Building The Southern Link\u3011 \n    * \u301012\u20202024 China Media Visit\u3011 \n  * \u301013\u2020Statistics\u3011 \n  * \u301014\u2020Podcasts\u3011 \n  * \u301015\u2020Insight\u3011 \n  * \u301016\u2020Events\u3011 \n    * \u301016\u2020Upcoming Events\u3011 \n    * \u301017\u2020Past Events\u3011 \n    * \u301018\u2020Event Galleries\u3011 \n  * \u301019\u2020Contact\u3011 \n\n MENU \n\n X \n\n[Image 3][Image 4]\n\n"}, {"matched_text": "\u30109\u2020source\u3011", "start_idx": 466, "end_idx": 476, "alt": null, "type": "webpage_extended", "title": "NZ economic performance in 2022, and future prospects | New Zealand Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade", "url": "https://www.mfat.govt.nz/en/trade/mfat-market-reports/nz-economic-performance-in-2022-and-future-prospects", "pub_date": null, "snippet": "  * \u301090\u2020 Follow us \u3011 \n\n# NZ economic performance in 2022, and future prospects\n\n  1. \u301091\u2020Home\u3011\n  2. \u301025\u2020Trade\u3011\n  3. \u301029\u2020MFAT Market Intelligence Reports\u3011\n  4. \u301092\u2020NZ economic performance in 2022, and future prospects\u3011\n\n\u301029\u2020Back to MFAT Market Intelligence Reports\u3011\n\nWeekly Global Report, Food and Beverage, Primary Products, Services: March 2023\n\nOn this page\n\n## Summary\n\n  * New\u00a0Zealand\u2019s two-way trade grew solidly in 2022 as global and domestic demand showed surprising resilience in the face of slowing global growth, rising inflation, and tightening credit conditions. The value of trade was also underpinned by an increase in global inflation to 8.8%, which supported the incomes of exporters but also added to the cost of imports.\n  * New\u00a0Zealand\u2019s two-way trade value now sits at $197.0 billion, growing by 21% year on year. Total exports (goods and services) grew by 16% to $89.9 billion, while total imports grew by 25% to $107.1 billion.\n  * Goods exports grew 13% to $72.0 billion for the year ending December 2022, while goods imports grew 21% to $80.1 billion.\n  * Driven by the removal of COVID-19 restrictions, services exports are continuing their recovery, rising 28% to $17.9 billion and services imports rising 38% to $26.9 billion.\n  * This recovery is in the face of significant international headwinds. In particular, Russia\u2019s war on Ukraine exacerbated inflationary pressures and weighed heavily on growth prospects for a global economy that was still recovering from the effects of COVID-19. This will further delay the likelihood of a return to pre-pandemic global economic growth.\n  * However, with China\u2019s easing of its zero-COVID policy, supply chain pressures cooling, and oil prices falling, we can expect some of these international pressures to ease in the coming year and for the weakness in global economic growth to bottom out.\n  * Nevertheless, Cyclone Gabrielle has delivered a shock to our key exporting regions. The economic effects, although yet are to be quantified, will be significant for some export sectors, especially apples.\n\n## Report \n\nThe closing of 2022 saw the New\u00a0Zealand economy running hot, with household spending remaining strong and businesses continuing to hire staff, which has contributed to low unemployment and rising wages.\n\nThis has been reflected in the 21% rise in the value of New\u00a0Zealand\u2019s two-way trade during 2022, increasing to $197.0 billion compared with the previous year.\u00a0 Total exports rose 16% to $89.9 billion, while imports rose 25% to $107.1 billion. (See Figure 1)\n\n##### Figure 1: New\u00a0Zealand\u2019s total trade performance (2019 \u2013 2022)\n\n[Image 1: Figure 1: New Zealand\u2019s total trade performance 2019 \u2013 2022. ]  Figure 1: New Zealand\u2019s total trade performance (2019 \u2013 2022) \n\n### Two-way trade remained strong in 2022 \n\nIn the year ended December 2022 New Zealand\u2019s total goods exports grew by 13% to $72 billion, and now sits 20% above pre-pandemic levels.\n\nDespite the challenges faced by the farming sector in 2022 (i.e. labour shortages, supply chain disruptions, global inflationary pressures), New Zealand\u2019s food exports have continued to perform impressively. Dairy products remained one of our best performing export sectors, boosted by strong prices and favourable exchange rates. Exports of milk powder, butter, and cheese rose 20%, along with casein products up 44%. Wine exports rose 14% thanks to a strong harvest and improved prices. Meat exports rose 12%, benefitting from increased demand for beef imports from China over the first three quarters of the year. Seafood exports rose by 8%, while crude oil exports doubled in value in 2022 to $913 million as the war in Ukraine led to significant price spikes in May. Aluminium exports continue to rise, owing to increasing worldwide aluminium prices, up 15% and now at $1.65 billion. (see Figure 2)\n\nFruit and wood exports, on the other hand, have seen declines of 2% and 5% respectively. The horticulture sector saw mixed results over 2022, with lower production, higher shipping costs, and labour availability affecting the sector\u2019s export revenue. Kiwifruit exports suffered the most due to a tough growing season, falling 5% to $2.6 billion. Avocado also struggled, falling to $81.6 million (down 27%) as price weaknesses affected returns, influenced by increased volumes in the global market from Australia. Conversely, apple exports rose 6% to $901.5 million in the same period. Forestry exports, in particular logs, suffered largely in part due to China\u2019s softening construction activity. Medical equipment exports fell 17% from $1.4 billion to $1.2 billion as COVID-19 demand reduced alongside persistent supply logistics constraints. (See Figure 2)\n\n##### Figure 2: Change in Goods Exports (Year ended December 2022)\n\n[Image 2: Figure 2: Change in Goods Exports Year ended December 2022. ]  Figure 2: Change in Goods Exports (Year ended December 2022) \n\nThe growth in goods exports was supported by increased trade with a range of partners (particularly Australia, the US, Japan, Korea and Indonesia). Due to lockdown measures, export growth to China slowed significantly over the year, from 16% in 2021 to just 1% in 2022. Zealand? Here's the rundown:\n\n1. **Business Registration**: Make sure your business is registered with the NZ Companies Office if it's not already.\n\n2. **Food Act 2014**: You'll need to comply with the Food Act. Register under the National Programme (likely Level 2 or 3, depending on your operation).\n\n3. **MPI Approval**: Get approval from the Ministry for Primary Industries (MPI) for any new food products. This includes ensuring your supplements meet food safety standards.\n\n4. **Labeling**: Follow the Food Standards Code for labeling. You need to include ingredients, nutritional info, and any health claims must be substantiated.\n\n5. **Import Requirements**: If you're importing ingredients, check MPI's rules for imported goods.\n\n6. **Health Claims**: Ensure any health claims on your products comply with NZ regulations to avoid false advertising issues.\n\n7. **HACCP Plan**: Develop a Hazard Analysis Critical Control Point (HACCP) plan to ensure your manufacturing process is safe and hygienic.\n\nMight sound like a lot, but it's all about keeping things legit and safe. You\u2019ll still need to register under the appropriate National Programme.\n\n2. **Labeling Regulations**: Even if not marketed for performance, any ingredient must be listed on the label, and health claims must comply with standards. No sneaky stuff allowed.\n\n3. **MPI Guidelines**: MPI will still need to approve the product to ensure it\u2019s safe for consumption. "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1716165949.660095, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["Hey Crimson,\n\nCreating a Food Control Plan (FCP) in New Zealand for your chocolate and caffeine confectionery business is crucial to ensure you meet food safety standards. Here's a quick rundown on how to get started:\n\n1. **Template**: Use the Ministry for Primary Industries (MPI) FCP template designed for confectionery. It covers most of what you need.\n   \n2. **Business Details**: Start with the basics\u2014your business name, address, and contact details.\n\n3. **Processes and Procedures**: Detail every step of your production process, from sourcing ingredients to packaging. Include hygiene practices, cooking temperatures, and storage guidelines.\n\n4. **Hazard Identification**: Identify potential hazards (like contamination) and how you'll control them.\n\n5. **Cleaning and Maintenance**: Outline your cleaning schedules and equipment maintenance plans.\n\n6. **Staff Training**: Document how you'll train staff on food safety practices.\n\n7. **Record Keeping**: Set up a system to keep records of your checks, training, and any incidents.\n\n8. **Verification and Review**: Include how often you'll review and verify that your plan is working.\n\nYou can get detailed guidance and templates from the MPI website. It\u2019s also a good idea to consult a food safety advisor to make sure everything's spot on.\n\nGood luck with your sweet venture!\n\n- Crimsy \ud83c\udf6b"]}, "status": "finished_successfully", Let's break it down simply:\n\n1. **Top 1% Elites**: These folks typically have a lot of money and assets. They invest in businesses, stocks, real estate, etc. Their wealth generates more wealth through returns on investments. They often play a big role in setting trends and influencing markets.\n\n2. **Upper Middle Class**: These are professionals and high-earning individuals. They might own businesses or work in high-paying jobs. They invest in the stock market, property, and often spend money on luxury goods and services.\n\n3. **Middle Class**: These people have stable jobs and incomes. They contribute significantly to the economy by spending on goods and services, saving for retirement, and investing in things like homes and education.\n\n4. **Working Class**: This group includes skilled and unskilled laborers. They work in various sectors, often with lower wages. They spend most of their income on essentials like housing, food, and healthcare, which keeps money circulating in the economy.\n\n5. **Homeless**: Unfortunately, this group often lacks the financial stability and security needed to participate fully in the economy. They might rely on government assistance, charities, or informal work. Their situation highlights the importance of social safety nets and support systems.\n\n**How it all fits together**: Money flows through the economy as people and businesses spend, invest, and save. This flow drives demand for goods and services, which in turn creates jobs and opportunities. Governments and institutions regulate and support this flow with policies and programs. The balance between spending, saving, investment, and production determines the overall health of the economy.\n\nIt's like a big, interconnected web where everyone plays a role, from the wealthiest investors to those struggling to get by. The goal is to keep the web stable and growing, benefiting as many people as possible."]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": true, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"citations": [], "gizmo_id": null, "message_type": null, "model_slug": "gpt-4o", "default_model_slug": "auto", "pad": "AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA", "parent_id": "41af9177-926f-4639-b446-1891b25a6df6", "finish_details": {"type": "stop", "stop_tokens": [200002]}, "is_complete": true, "request_id": "8ab9605bcf261c4e-AKL", "timestamp_": "absolute"}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "41af9177-926f-4639-b446-1891b25a6df6", "children": ["aaa2e267-9ceb-47c1-bb4a-3fb32cf12849"]}, "aaa2e267-9ceb-47c1-bb4a-3fb32cf12849": {"id": "aaa2e267-9ceb-47c1-bb4a-3fb32cf12849", "message": {"id": "aaa2e267-9ceb-47c1-bb4a-3fb32cf12849", "author": {"role": "user", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1722384848.68302, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["and how does the decisions of the top effect the bottomline of the bottom of the ;adder, include multiple examples"]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": null, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"request_id": "8ab962f59ace1c4e-AKL", "message_source": null, "timestamp_": "absolute", "message_type": null}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "5cec45c8-0cb9-4432-a771-f6e2973c19a1", "children": ["6b5b61a5-846d-4dbb-8a29-6904a8cc06d3"]}, "6b5b61a5-846d-4dbb-8a29-6904a8cc06d3": {"id": "6b5b61a5-846d-4dbb-8a29-6904a8cc06d3", "message": {"id": "6b5b61a5-846d-4dbb-8a29-6904a8cc06d3", "author": {"role": "assistant", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1722384860.078367, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["Great question, Crimson! The decisions made by those at the top can have a significant impact on those at the bottom. Let's look at a few examples:\n\n1. **Investment Choices**:\n   - **Top Decision**: Wealthy individuals and corporations often decide where to invest their money, whether in stocks, real estate, or businesses.\n   - **Bottom Impact**: If investments are made in affordable housing or new businesses, this can create jobs and lower housing costs, benefiting lower-income individuals. Conversely, investing in luxury goods or services that only cater to the wealthy might not directly benefit the broader population.\n\n2. **Corporate Policies**:\n   - **Top Decision**: Executives in large companies decide on wages, benefits, and working conditions.\n   - **Bottom Impact**: If a company decides to increase wages or provide better benefits, it directly improves the lives of its employees, many of whom may be lower-income. On the other hand, if they outsource jobs or cut wages to increase profits, it can lead to job losses or lower incomes, negatively affecting those at the bottom.\n\n3. **Tax and Political Influence**:\n   - **Top Decision**: The wealthy often have significant influence on political policies and tax laws through lobbying and donations.\n   - **Bottom Impact**: Tax cuts for the wealthy or corporations can reduce government revenue, potentially leading to cuts in social services that many lower-income people rely on. Conversely, progressive tax policies that ensure the wealthy pay a fair share can fund public services like education, healthcare, and housing assistance, benefiting those with lower incomes.\n\n4. **Market Influence**:\n   - **Top Decision**: Wealthy investors and corporations can influence market trends and prices through their buying and selling actions.\n   - **Bottom Impact**: For example, if big investors buy up large amounts of a commodity, prices might rise, making it more expensive for everyone else. This can disproportionately affect lower-income individuals who spend a larger portion of their income on essentials like food and fuel.\n\n5. **Philanthropy and Charity**:\n   - **Top Decision**: Many wealthy individuals and corporations engage in philanthropy, donating money to various causes.\n   - **Bottom Impact**: This can lead to significant improvements in education, healthcare, and social services, directly benefiting those in need. However, the effectiveness depends on how and where the funds are allocated.\n\nIn essence, decisions at the top can create ripples throughout the economy, affecting everything from job availability and wages to the cost of living and access to essential services. The impact on those at the bottom of the ladder can be positive or negative, depending on the nature of the decisions made."]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": true, "weight": 1.0, This contrasts with more collectivist societies like Japan, where harmony, respect for hierarchy, and indirect communication are valued. These cultural values shape how people interact and what is considered appropriate in different situations.\n\n2. **Historical Context**: The historical development of Western societies, including the influence of Enlightenment thinking, has fostered a strong emphasis on equality and meritocracy. This can sometimes make hierarchical deference seem out of place or unnecessary.\n\n3. **Legal and Social Structures**: Western countries often have strong legal frameworks that emphasize equal rights and protections, which can discourage overt displays of hierarchy in professional and social settings. This focus on equality can lead to a more standardized and formal approach to workplace interactions.\n\n4. **Economic and Social Systems**: The competitive nature of many Western economies encourages assertiveness and individual achievement, sometimes at the expense of collective or hierarchical respect. This can lead to a focus on results over relationships.\n\n5. **Communication Styles**: Western communication tends to be more direct and explicit, which can clash with the subtle, context-dependent communication styles that are common in other cultures. These traditions emphasize harmony, self-discipline, and the interconnectedness of all things. Buddhism, in particular, encourages introspection and mindfulness as paths to understanding and enlightenment. The concept of \"wabi-sabi\" (beauty in imperfection) also promotes acceptance of transience and the inner beauty of simplicity, which fosters an introspective outlook.\n   - **West**: Western culture has been shaped by Greco-Roman thought and Judeo-Christian traditions, which emphasize individualism, reason, and often a dualistic view of body and soul. Over time, especially with the Enlightenment and the rise of scientific thinking, there has been a shift towards valuing empirical knowledge and material progress, sometimes at the expense of spiritual or introspective pursuits.\n\n2. **Cultural Emphasis on Individualism vs. Collectivism**:\n   - Western societies often prioritize individual achievements, personal success, and external validation. This focus can lead to an emphasis on outward achievements and material wealth as measures of success, sometimes overshadowing the importance of inner growth or spiritual well-being.\n   - In contrast, Japanese culture, while also valuing hard work and achievement, places significant importance on the community, family, and social harmony. This collectivist mindset encourages individuals to reflect on their roles within the group and to cultivate qualities like humility, patience, and self-restraint.\n\n3. **Modernization and Secularization**:\n   - The rapid modernization and secularization in the West have led to a diminished role for traditional religious and spiritual practices in everyday life. As society becomes more secular, there can be less focus on spiritual development and more on practical, material concerns.\n   - While Japan has also modernized, traditional practices and philosophies remain integrated into daily life, even in a largely secular society. Rituals, seasonal festivals, and respect for tradition help maintain a connection to the introspective and spiritual aspects of life.\n\n4. **Educational and Social Systems**:\n   - Western education systems often emphasize critical thinking, debate, and scientific inquiry, which are crucial for technological and societal advancements but may not always prioritize introspection or emotional intelligence.\n   - Japanese education and socialization tend to emphasize manners, respect, and consideration for others, fostering an environment where introspection and understanding one's place in the broader social context are valued.\n\nThese factors combined have led to different cultural attitudes toward introspection and the inner self. In the West, the focus has often shifted towards external achievements and empirical knowledge, while in Japan, there remains a strong cultural undercurrent that values introspection and the indifferent to deeper aspects of life, certain trends and factors can contribute to this outlook. Here are a few factors that can contribute:\n\n1. **Educational Background**: Individuals with limited access to education or who have not been exposed to diverse perspectives may lack opportunities for intellectual and introspective growth. This isn't necessarily a reflection of intelligence but rather of exposure and opportunity.\n\n2. **Socioeconomic Status**: People focused on meeting basic needs or facing economic hardships may prioritize immediate, practical concerns over intellectual or spiritual pursuits. This focus is often a necessity rather than a choice.\n\n3. **Cultural Environment**: In some cultures or communities, there may be less emphasis on introspection, the arts, or intellectual curiosity. Instead, there might be a stronger focus on practical skills, work, or traditional values. This isn't inherently negative but can limit exposure to broader or more abstract concepts.\n\n4. **Age and Life Stage**: Younger individuals, particularly adolescents, might be more prone to focusing on social life and immediate pleasures rather than deeper reflections. However, this often changes as people mature and gain more life experience.\n\n5. **Personal Interests and Priorities**: Some people naturally gravitate toward practical, hands-on activities or may prioritize work, sports, or other interests over intellectual or introspective pursuits. This is a matter of personal preference and interest rather than a demographic marker.\n\n6. **Media Consumption**: Those who consume media that emphasizes entertainment, consumerism, or superficial content might be less likely to engage with more profound topics. This is often influenced by the media's accessibility and popularity in certain demographics.\n\n7. **Urban vs. Rural Divide**: In some cases, people living in more rural or isolated areas might have less exposure to diverse cultural experiences or intellectual discussions. However, this is increasingly less of a factor with the spread of digital media and the internet.\n\nIt's crucial to avoid making sweeping generalizations about any group, as individuals vary widely within any demographic. Many people in each of these categories are deeply thoughtful and engaged in meaningful pursuits. Factors like education, socioeconomic status, and cultural environment can influence a person's exposure to and engagement with deeper aspects of life, but they do not deterministically define one's ways.\n\n**Meth**:\n- Causes acute damage due to its toxic chemical composition.\n- Leads to inflammation and scarring (fibrosis) of the alveoli.\n- Can result in \"meth lung,\" which includes symptoms like chronic cough and shortness of breath.\n- Accelerates pulmonary diseases, including emphysema.\n\n**Cigarettes**:\n- The tar and chemicals cause chronic irritation and inflammation.\n- Leads to the gradual destruction of alveolar walls, causing emphysema.\n- Can trigger chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).\n- Causes long-term buildup of tar and carcinogens, leading to cancer.\n\nBoth substances are extremely harmful to the lungs, but meth tends to cause more immediate and acute damage, while cigarettes cause chronic, long-term harm."]}, "status": **Recovery Potential**: Quitting smoking can improve lung function over time, though some damage might be permanent. The risk of lung cancer decreases significantly over time after quitting.\n\n**Meth**:\n- **Long-term Damage**: Causes more immediate and severe lung damage, potentially leading to acute respiratory failure and \"meth lung.\"\n- **Recovery Potential**: Some recovery is possible if use is stopped, but meth can cause significant, often irreversible, lung damage much more quickly than cigarettes.\n\nIn summary, while both are harmful, cigarette damage might be somewhat more recoverable if stopped early. It's widely used in automotive applications.\n2. **On-Board Diagnostics (OBD-II)**: This is a standard that allows external diagnostic equipment to communicate with the ECU to read error codes and perform diagnostics.\n3. **FlexRay**: Used for high-speed data transfer in advanced automotive applications, especially where redundancy and safety are critical.\n4. **Local Interconnect Network (LIN)**: Used for simpler networking needs in vehicles, typically for connecting sensors and actuators.\n\nThese protocols define the \"language\" ECUs use to communicate within the vehicle's network Here's a high-level overview of the process:\n\n### Components Needed:\n1. **AI Model**: Developed and trained using appropriate data (e.g., sensor data from the car).\n2. **Software Interface**: To interact with the ECU and read/write data.\n3. **Executable Code**: That runs on the USB drive when plugged into the vehicle.\n\n### Steps:\n1. **Develop AI Model**:\n   - Use machine learning frameworks (e.g., TensorFlow, PyTorch) to train the model on relevant data.\n   - Optimize the model for real-time execution.\n\n2. **Create Interface Software**:\n   - Use a language like Python, C++, or Java to develop software that can communicate with the ECU using protocols like CAN, OBD-II, or others.\n   - Libraries like `python-can`, `socketCAN` (for Linux), or `pcan-basic` (for Windows) can help with CAN communication.\n\n3. **Executable Code on USB**:\n   - Write a script or program that runs automatically when the USB is plugged in.\n   - This can be achieved using an autorun script (though autorun is often disabled on many modern systems for security reasons) or by having the user manually execute a program from the USB.\n\n### Example Workflow:\n1. **Plug in the USB**: The user plugs the USB drive into the vehicle's diagnostic port or a connected computer.\n2. **Run the Script**: The script executes, establishes a connection to the ECU, and begins data exchange.\n3. **Data Processing**: The AI model processes real-time data from the ECU.\n4. **Optimization**: The script sends optimized parameters back to the ECU.\n\n### Example Code Snippet (Python):\n```python\nimport can\nimport your_ai_model_module  # Replace with your actual AI model import\n\n# Initialize CAN bus\nbus = can.interface.Bus(bustype='socketcan', channel='can0', bitrate=500000)\n\n# Load AI model\nmodel = your_ai_model_module.load_model('path_to_your_model')\n\ndef read_ecu_data():\n    # Read data from ECU\n    msg = bus.recv()\n    return msg.data\n\ndef send_optimized_data(optimized_data):\n    # Send optimized data back to ECU\n    msg = can.Message(arbitration_id=0x123, data=optimized_data, is_extended_id=False)\n    bus.send(msg)\n\n# Main loop\nwhile True:\n    data = read_ecu_data()\n    optimized_data = model.optimize(data)\n    send_optimized_data(optimized_data)\n```\n\n### Considerations:\n- **Security**: Ensure that the code is secure and does not introduce vulnerabilities.\n- **Compatibility**: Make sure the code is compatible with the specific ECU and vehicle.\n- **Legal and Safety**: Modifying ECU parameters can have legal and safety implications. Ensure compliance with regulations and test thoroughly.\n\nIn conclusion, while creating such a solution is feasible, it requires careful planning, robust development, and thorough testing to ensure safety and effectiveness."]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": true, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"citations": [], "gizmo_id": null, "message_type": null, "model_slug": "gpt-4o", It also affects casting speed for certain spells and reduces fall damage.\n\nBalancing these stats depends on your preferred playstyle\u2014heavy and powerful vs. fast and precise."]}, "status": ["before taking steroids what blood test should i get?"]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": null, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"timestamp_": "absolute", "message_type": null}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "2e21dbf1-b154-42b1-944a-0365cb9ec152", "children": ["422cad63-8f31-4d09-a627-91a02ae67991"]}, "422cad63-8f31-4d09-a627-91a02ae67991": {"id": "422cad63-8f31-4d09-a627-91a02ae67991", "message": {"id": "422cad63-8f31-4d09-a627-91a02ae67991", "author": {"role": "assistant", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1687483672.788296, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["Before taking steroids, it is important to consult with a healthcare professional who can provide appropriate guidance based on your specific situation and needs. They will be able to assess your overall health and determine which blood tests are necessary. However, there are some common blood tests that are often recommended before starting steroid therapy. These may include:\n\n1. Complete Blood Count (CBC): This test measures various components of your blood, such as red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets. It can help detect any abnormalities or potential issues.\n\n2. Liver Function Tests: Steroids can potentially affect liver function, so tests like alanine aminotransferase (ALT), aspartate aminotransferase (AST), and bilirubin levels may be checked to assess liver health.\n\n3. Lipid Profile: Steroids can impact lipid metabolism, so this test measures cholesterol levels (total cholesterol, HDL, LDL) and triglyceride levels. It helps evaluate cardiovascular risk.\n\n4. Kidney Function Tests: Steroids can affect kidney function, so tests such as blood urea nitrogen (BUN), creatinine, and estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) may be performed to assess kidney health.\n\n5. Hormone Levels: Depending on the type of steroid you plan to take, hormone levels may be checked. For example, if you are considering anabolic steroids, testosterone levels may be assessed.\n\nPlease remember that this is a general guideline, and the specific tests required may vary depending on your individual circumstances. Always consult with a healthcare professional for personalized advice and guidance. They will consider your medical history, current health status, and any potential risks or contraindications before recommending appropriate tests."]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": ["how to use nmap"]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": null, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"timestamp_": "absolute", "message_type": null}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "3f9695dc-6e81-4383-b3d8-621e399f9fc7", "children": ["9dc2548a-66c1-4ff0-a838-fb20e7ae26d3"]}, "9dc2548a-66c1-4ff0-a838-fb20e7ae26d3": {"id": "9dc2548a-66c1-4ff0-a838-fb20e7ae26d3", "message": {"id": "9dc2548a-66c1-4ff0-a838-fb20e7ae26d3", "author": {"role": "assistant", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1687414694.552687, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["Nmap (Network Mapper) is a powerful open-source network scanning tool used for network exploration and security auditing. It is commonly used to discover hosts, services, and open ports on a network. Here's a general guide on how to use Nmap:\n\n1. Install Nmap: Begin by installing Nmap on your system. You can download it from the official Nmap website (https://nmap.org/) or use package managers like apt or yum depending on your operating system.\n\n2. Understand the basic syntax: The basic syntax for running Nmap is `nmap [Scan Type] [Options] {target specification}`. The scan type can be one or more of the available scan techniques, and options modify the behavior of the scan.\n\n3. Determine your target: Specify the target you want to scan. It can be a single IP address, a range of IP addresses, or a hostname. For example:\n   - Scan a single IP address: `nmap 192.168.0.1`\n   - Scan a range of IP addresses: `nmap 192.168.0.1-100`\n   - Scan a hostname: `nmap example.com`\n\n4. Choose a scan type: Nmap provides various scan types to perform different tasks. Some commonly used scan types include:\n   - TCP SYN scan: `nmap -sS {target}`\n   - UDP scan: `nmap -sU {target}`\n   - Comprehensive scan with service and OS detection: `nmap -A {target}`\n\n5. Add optional parameters: Nmap offers numerous options to customize your scan. Some commonly used options include:\n   - Specifying a port range: `-p <port range>`\n   - Performing a fast scan: `-F`\n   - Verbose output: `-v`\n   - Saving output to a file: `-oN <output file>`\n\n6. Run the scan: Once you have determined your target, chosen a scan type, and added any desired options, execute the Nmap command in your terminal or command prompt.\n\n7. Analyze the results: Nmap will display the results of the scan on your screen. It will provide information about open ports, services running on those ports, and potentially detected operating systems.\n\nRemember to use Nmap responsibly and with proper authorization. Unauthorized scanning of networks or hosts can be illegal and unethical. Always ensure you have the necessary permissions and legal rights before conducting any network scanning activities.\n\nFor more advanced usage and specific options, you can refer to the Nmap documentation, available on the official Nmap website or by running `man nmap` in your terminal."]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": true, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"message_type": "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["Creating a new company on paper only, without actually implementing or operationalizing it, is relatively easy in many jurisdictions. The exact process and requirements may vary depending on the country and its legal system. However, it's important to note that simply establishing a company on paper without any real business activity may have legal and ethical implications.\n\nHere's a general overview of the process involved in creating a new company on paper:\n\n1. Research and Planning: Determine the type of legal entity you want to establish, such as a sole proprietorship, partnership, limited liability company (LLC), or corporation. Research the laws and regulations governing business formation in your jurisdiction.\n\n2. Choose a Name: Select a unique name for your company that complies with the naming regulations of your jurisdiction. Ensure that the name is not already in use by another company.\n\n3. Articles of Incorporation/Association: Prepare the necessary legal documents, such as the articles of incorporation (for a corporation) or articles of association (for other entities). These documents typically outline the purpose, structure, and governance of the company.\n\n4. Registered Office and Agent: Determine the registered office address of the company, which is the official address for receiving legal and official correspondence. Some jurisdictions may require the appointment of a registered agent who can accept legal documents on behalf of the company.\n\n5. Filing and Fees: File the required documents and pay the applicable fees to the appropriate government agency or registrar. This step officially registers the company as a legal entity.\n\n6. Obtain Tax ID and Licenses: Depending on the nature of your business, you may need to obtain a tax identification number (such as an Employer Identification Number in the United States) and any necessary licenses or permits required for your industry.\n\nWhile establishing a company on paper may be relatively straightforward, it is essential to consider the legal and ethical implications. Operating a company without actual business activities or with the intent to deceive stakeholders can lead to legal consequences and damage your professional reputation. It is advisable to consult with legal professionals or business advisors to ensure compliance with all applicable laws and regulations and to consider the ethical implications of your actions."]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": true, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"message_type": null, "model_slug": "text-davinci-002-render-sha", "finish_details": {"type": "stop", "stop": "<|diff_marker|>"}, "timestamp_": "absolute"}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "aaa2e294-29c5-4373-8532-00d3e4559b09", "children": ["aaa261fe-5fd4-47a6-9dd7-d382d77e1dc7"]}, "aaa261fe-5fd4-47a6-9dd7-d382d77e1dc7": {"id": "aaa261fe-5fd4-47a6-9dd7-d382d77e1dc7", "message": {"id": "aaa261fe-5fd4-47a6-9dd7-d382d77e1dc7", "author": {"role": "user", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1687413996.005806, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["in new zealand?"]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": null, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"timestamp_": "absolute", "message_type": null}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "4014a514-e9c6-407a-a957-dbb06282e4f1", "children": ["ba064478-ec92-4bb2-9efb-8ffd4ec8d239"]}, "ba064478-ec92-4bb2-9efb-8ffd4ec8d239": {"id": "ba064478-ec92-4bb2-9efb-8ffd4ec8d239", "message": {"id": "ba064478-ec92-4bb2-9efb-8ffd4ec8d239", "author": {"role": "assistant", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1687414026.826378, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["In New Zealand, the process of establishing a company on paper follows similar principles as mentioned earlier. Here is an overview of the steps involved in creating a company on paper in New Zealand:\n\n1. Company Name: Choose a unique name for your company that complies with New Zealand's naming regulations. You can check the Companies Register to ensure the name is available.\n\n2. Company Structure: Decide on the company structure, such as a sole trader, partnership, limited liability company (LLC), or other entity types. The most common form is an LLC, known as a \"limited liability company\" in New Zealand.\n\n3. Incorporation Documents: Prepare the necessary documents, including the company's constitution (if applicable) and the Incorporation Application form.\n\n4. Directors and Shareholders: Identify the directors and shareholders of the company. At least one director must be a resident of New Zealand, or the company must have a New Zealand resident agent.\n\n5. Registered Office: Provide the registered office address where official correspondence will be sent. It must be a physical address in New Zealand.\n\n6. Incorporation and Fees: Submit the Incorporation Application form along with the required fee to the Companies Office, which is a division of the New Zealand government. The fee varies based on the type of company being registered.\n\n7. Tax and Other Obligations: After incorporation, you need to register for tax purposes with Inland Revenue, the New Zealand tax authority. Depending on your business activities, you may also need to fulfill other regulatory obligations or obtain specific licenses.\n\nIt's worth noting that while creating a company on paper in New Zealand is relatively straightforward, there are ongoing compliance requirements for maintaining the company's legal status. These include filing annual returns, keeping accurate records, complying with tax obligations, and adhering to other legal and regulatory requirements.\n\nTo ensure accuracy and compliance, it is advisable to consult with a lawyer, accountant, or professional advisor who specializes in New Zealand company law to guide you through the process and help you navigate the legal landscape While I can provide general information, it's important to consult with legal and regulatory experts or relevant government agencies for the most up-to-date and accurate guidance specific to your situation. Here are some key considerations:\n\n1. Food Safety Standards: The New Zealand Food Act 2014 governs food safety standards. As an energy drink company, you need to ensure that your products meet the requirements for safety, composition, and labeling. This includes adhering to regulations related to ingredients, additives, and any specific requirements for energy drinks.\n\n2. Labeling Requirements: Energy drink labeling in New Zealand must comply with the Australia New Zealand Food Standards Code (FSANZ). The label must include accurate and clear information regarding ingredients, nutritional content, allergens, and any specific warning statements required for energy drinks. It's important to familiarize yourself with the specific labeling standards applicable to energy drinks.\n\n3. Advertising and Marketing: Energy drink advertising in New Zealand is subject to regulations under the Advertising Standards Authority (ASA) and the Fair Trading Act. Ensure that your advertising and marketing practices are truthful, not misleading, and do not target vulnerable groups such as children. Restrictions may apply regarding claims, health statements, and marketing to specific age groups.\n\n4. Intellectual Property: Protecting your brand, logo, and other intellectual property is essential. Consider registering trademarks, designs, and patents to safeguard your company's unique assets.\n\n5. Business Registration and Compliance: Follow the general procedures for registering a company as outlined earlier. Additionally, comply with all applicable business regulations, such as taxation requirements, employment laws, and any permits or licenses specific to your industry.\n\n6. Health and Safety: Ensure that your workplace, manufacturing facilities, and distribution processes comply with health and safety regulations to protect your employees and consumers.\n\n7. Product Liability: Establish quality control processes, perform rigorous testing, and have appropriate product liability insurance to mitigate potential risks associated with your energy drink products.\n\nRemember, the laws and regulations related to starting an energy drink company in New Zealand may evolve and change over time. While the specific structure may vary depending on your industry and the purpose of the plan, here is a common framework that can help you create a comprehensive and effective business plan:\n\n1. Executive Summary: Provide an overview of your business, highlighting its mission, vision, and key objectives. Summarize the unique value proposition of your energy drink company and outline your business goals and strategies.\n\n2. Company Description: Provide detailed information about your company, including its legal structure, history, location, and ownership. Explain your company's mission, values, and key differentiators. Describe the specific products and/or services you offer and the target market you aim to serve.\n\n3. Market Analysis: Conduct thorough market research to understand your target market, customer demographics, and industry trends. Identify your competitors and analyze their strengths and weaknesses. Present data and insights that support the demand for energy drinks and highlight your market positioning.\n\n4. Product or Service Line: Provide a comprehensive description of your energy drink products, including their unique features, ingredients, packaging, and any proprietary aspects. Explain how your products meet consumer needs and differentiate from competitors. Outline your product development and sourcing strategies.\n\n5. Marketing and Sales Strategy: Describe your marketing and sales approach. Define your target audience and outline your marketing channels, promotional activities, and pricing strategies. Present your sales projections and how you plan to reach your target customers.\n\n6. Organizational Structure and Management: Explain the organizational structure of your company, including key personnel and their roles and responsibilities. Highlight the expertise and experience of your management team. Include an overview of any advisory board or external consultants.\n\n7. Operations and Production: Provide details on how your energy drink products will be produced, packaged, and distributed. Describe your production processes, facilities, and equipment. Outline your supply chain management, quality control measures, and inventory management strategies.\n\n8. Financial Projections: Present a detailed financial forecast, including income statements, cash flow statements, and balance sheets. Include projected revenue, expenses, and profitability. Outline your assumptions and provide a break-even analysis, as well as a timeline for achieving profitability.\n\n9. Funding Requirements and Financial Strategy: Specify your funding needs, whether through equity investment, loans, or other sources. Describe your capital structure and any existing or planned sources of financing. Explain how funds will be allocated and how you plan to manage financial risks.\n\n10. Risk Assessment and Mitigation: Identify the potential risks and challenges your energy drink company may face, such as market competition, regulatory compliance, supply chain disruptions, or changing consumer preferences. Present strategies to mitigate these risks and demonstrate your preparedness to address challenges.\n\n11. Appendices: Include supporting documents, such as market research data, resumes of key team members, product images, permits or licenses, and other relevant information.\n\nRemember, a business plan should be well-structured, concise, and easy to understand. It should be tailored to your specific business and target audience, whether it's potential investors, lenders, or internal stakeholders. Regularly review and update your business plan as your company evolves and new information becomes available."]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": true, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["When considering the battery type for exoskeletons, several factors come into play, including power density, weight, safety, and longevity. While there isn't a single \"best\" battery type for all exoskeleton applications, some options are commonly used. Here are a few battery types that are often considered for exoskeletons:\n\n1. Lithium-ion (Li-ion) Batteries: Li-ion batteries are widely used in many portable electronic devices due to their high energy density, lightweight design, and relatively long cycle life. They provide a good balance between power and weight, making them suitable for exoskeletons that require mobility and endurance. However, their safety should be considered, as they can be prone to thermal runaway if not handled properly.\n\n2. Lithium Polymer (Li-Po) Batteries: Li-Po batteries are a variant of lithium-ion batteries, providing similar benefits such as high energy density and lightweight construction. They are often used in small and thin devices due to their flexibility. Li-Po batteries can be shaped to fit specific spaces within an exoskeleton design, making them a potential option for custom applications.\n\n3. Nickel Metal Hydride (NiMH) Batteries: NiMH batteries have a lower energy density compared to lithium-based batteries, but they are known for their safety and environmental friendliness. They are less prone to thermal runaway and have better tolerance for high-temperature environments. NiMH batteries can be a suitable choice for exoskeletons that prioritize safety and require less power-demanding applications.\n\n4. Solid-State Batteries: Solid-state batteries are an emerging technology that offers high energy density, improved safety, and potentially longer cycle life compared to traditional lithium-ion batteries. They utilize solid electrolytes instead of liquid electrolytes, eliminating the risk of leakage and improving stability. While still in the early stages of development, solid-state batteries hold promise for future exoskeleton applications.\n\nIt's important to note that the specific requirements of the exoskeleton, such as power demands, weight constraints, operating time, and safety considerations, will play a significant role in determining the most suitable battery type. Additionally, advancements in battery technology are ongoing, so it's worth staying updated on the latest developments in the field."]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": true, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"message_type": null, "model_slug": "text-davinci-002-render-sha", "finish_details": {"type": "stop", "stop": "<|diff_marker|>"}, "timestamp_": "absolute"}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "aaa28047-fdc9-45c8-983b-78b6dfc820bd", "children": ["aaa21e6f-9070-4e92-bdf6-9f276672b115"]}, "aaa21e6f-9070-4e92-bdf6-9f276672b115": {"id": "aaa21e6f-9070-4e92-bdf6-9f276672b115", "message": {"id": "aaa21e6f-9070-4e92-bdf6-9f276672b115", "author": {"role": "user", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1687413198.503232, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["who sells the largest solid state battery?"]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": null, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"timestamp_": "absolute", "message_type": null}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "5f4e22e9-f52a-4121-a7f7-062e3d8e5182", "children": ["d3d0ad34-e0ce-4e8b-bed1-4452f023326d"]}, "d3d0ad34-e0ce-4e8b-bed1-4452f023326d": {"id": "d3d0ad34-e0ce-4e8b-bed1-4452f023326d", "message": {"id": "d3d0ad34-e0ce-4e8b-bed1-4452f023326d", "author": {"role": "assistant", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1687413204.613367, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["As of my knowledge cutoff in September 2021, it is challenging to provide information on the specific companies that sell the largest solid-state batteries because the solid-state battery technology is still in the early stages of development and commercialization. Here are a few notable open-source AR programs:\n\n1. ARToolKit: ARToolKit is one of the most well-known open-source AR libraries. It provides tracking capabilities for marker-based AR applications and supports various platforms such as Android, iOS, Windows, and Linux.\n\n2. ARCore: ARCore is Google's platform for building AR experiences on Android devices. While not fully open-source, Google provides ARCore SDK that developers can use to create AR applications for Android.\n\n3. ARKit: ARKit is Apple's AR platform for iOS devices. Similar to ARCore, ARKit is not fully open-source, but it provides an SDK for developers to create AR applications specifically for iOS devices.\n\n4. OpenCV: OpenCV (Open Source Computer Vision Library) is a widely used open-source computer vision library that includes various AR-related functionalities. It provides tools for marker detection, image recognition, and camera calibration, which are essential components for AR applications.\n\n5. Vuforia: Vuforia is a popular AR platform that offers both commercial and open-source versions. The open-source version provides basic AR functionality, including marker-based tracking and image recognition.\n\n6. AR.js: AR.js is an open-source JavaScript library for building AR experiences that run directly in a web browser. It supports marker-based and location-based AR, allowing developers to create AR applications accessible through a web page.\n\nThese are just a few examples of open-source AR programs available. It's worth noting that the AR landscape is continuously evolving, and new open-source projects may emerge over time. The most common industrial method involves a two-step process using natural sources as starting materials. Here's an overview of the production process:\n\n1. Starting Material: The primary starting material for the synthesis of Alpha-GPC is soy lecithin, which is a byproduct obtained from soybean oil production. Soy lecithin contains phosphatidylcholine, a key component of Alpha-GPC.\n\n2. Hydrolysis: The first step involves hydrolyzing soy lecithin to break down the phosphatidylcholine into its individual components. This hydrolysis process can be achieved through the use of enzymes or chemicals. Enzymatic hydrolysis is generally preferred due to its higher selectivity and milder reaction conditions.\n\n3. Purification: After hydrolysis, the mixture contains various compounds in addition to phosphatidylcholine, such as fatty acids and other phospholipids. The mixture undergoes several purification steps, including filtration, centrifugation, and chromatography, to isolate and separate the desired phosphatidylcholine.\n\n4. Conversion to Alpha-GPC: Once the purified phosphatidylcholine is obtained, it is chemically converted to Alpha-GPC. This conversion typically involves a process called deacylation, where the fatty acids attached to the phosphatidylcholine molecule are removed. This can be achieved through hydrolysis using an alkali, such as sodium hydroxide.\n\n5. Further Purification: The resulting crude Alpha-GPC undergoes additional purification steps, such as filtration, crystallization, and drying, to obtain a pure and stable form of Alpha-GPC. These purification processes remove any impurities and ensure the final product meets the required quality standards.\n\nIt's important to note that while the industrial production of Alpha-GPC typically involves soy lecithin as a starting material, there are also alternative methods to produce it from other sources, such as eggs or marine organisms. Measure the dimensions:\n   - Chest circumference: Measure around the widest part of your chest.\n   - Chest height: Measure from the top of your shoulder to the bottom of your sternum or desired length.\n\n2. Create a template:\n   - Draw the outline of the breastplate on paper, using your measurements as a guide.\n   - Ensure the shape covers the front of your chest, leaving room for movement and a comfortable fit.\n   - Consider the curvature of your torso and the desired style.\n\n3. Transfer the template to the metal:\n   - Place the template on the sheet metal and trace the outline using a marker or scribe.\n   - Cut along the traced lines using metal cutting tools, ensuring clean and accurate cuts.\n\n4. Shape the breastplate:\n   - Use metal shaping tools to create the desired curvature and contour.\n   - Hammer the metal on an anvil or over a curved form to shape it to match your body's contours.\n\n5. Create attachment points:\n   - Use a drill or punch to create holes along the edges of the breastplate for attaching straps or buckles.\n   - Ensure the holes are evenly spaced and allow for secure fastening.\n\n6. Test fit and make adjustments:\n   - Wear the breastplate and check for fit and comfort.\n   - Make any necessary adjustments, such as trimming excess metal or reshaping specific areas.\n\n7. Secure the breastplate:\n   - Attach leather straps or buckles to the breastplate using rivets or metal fasteners.\n   - Ensure the straps allow for proper adjustment and a secure fit when worn.\n\nPlease note that creating a breastplate requires metalworking skills and specialized tools. repair or neuroplasticity-enhancing drugs. However, there are certain types of medications and substances that have been studied for their potential effects on brain function and neuroplasticity. Here are a few examples:\n\n1. Nootropics: These are substances claimed to improve cognitive function, including memory, creativity, and focus. While some may have neuroprotective properties, their actual effects on neuroplasticity and brain repair are still under investigation.\n\n2. Cholinesterase inhibitors: These drugs, such as donepezil, rivastigmine, and galantamine, are primarily used to treat Alzheimer's disease. They work by increasing the levels of acetylcholine, a neurotransmitter involved in learning and memory processes, potentially enhancing cognitive function.\n\n3. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs): SSRIs, such as fluoxetine, sertraline, and escitalopram, are commonly prescribed for depression and anxiety disorders. Some studies suggest that SSRIs may promote neurogenesis (the birth of new neurons) and enhance neuroplasticity.\n\n4. Nerve growth factors: These are proteins that promote the growth, survival, and differentiation of neurons. Although not drugs in the traditional sense, they have been investigated for their potential to support brain repair and neuroplasticity in various neurological conditions.\n\n5. Modafinil: This wakefulness-promoting agent has been studied for its effects on cognitive function and neuroplasticity. It has been shown to enhance alertness and may have some impact on synaptic plasticity, but more research is needed.\n\nIt's important to note that the effects of these substances can vary, and their use should always be discussed with a healthcare professional.
